description.web: Altair vineyard, is located close to the town of Requinoa. The main factors that give character and complexity to their wine are their proximity to the mountains and the cool breezes that come down causing a natural temperature in the vineyard of 25 degrees and up, allowing them to extend the natural maturation of the fruit on the vine.

description.web: A beautiful isolated bay in the Almirantazgo Sound, Ainsworth Bay is found along the fjords of the Chilean coast and can be visited on board an adventure cruise . At Ainsworth Bay you can see the retreating Marinelli Glacier and watch elephant seals on the beaches. This is a difficult place to reach by any means other than by boat, and it is one of the most pristine and secluded spots to visit in this part of Chilean Patagonia.

description.web: Aguja Pollone, meaning the Pollone Needle, is a granite spire which can be seen in front of Mount Fizt Roy from the viewpoint at Laguna Pollone, just off the Electrico Valley.
description.quote: Aguja Pollone, meaning the Pollone Needle, is a granite spire which can be seen in front of Mount Fizt Roy from the viewpoint at Laguna Pollone, just off the Electrico Valley.

description.web: The Amalia or Skua Glacier is found in Bernardo O'Higgins National Park, and comes down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Field. It is a retreating glacier and is receding at an incredibly fast past compared with other glaciers in the region. This glacier partially surrounds Reclus Volcano and erodes its northern flank. The glacier is accessed by boat or, for the more adventurous explorers, by kayak.

description.web: Only accessible by boat or a 3 hour hike through the surrounding forest, Aguas Arriba is a secluded lodge on the shore of Lago del Desierto. The lodge has a homely feel with lovely hosts and only 6 rooms, and it is a wonderful place to relax whilst enjoying spectacular views of Mt. Fitz Roy, Mt. Torre and Glaciar Vespignani. Excursions on offer include trekking, boat trips and fly fishing. See our page on Aguas Arriba Lodge to find out more.

description.web: The capital of the Island of Chiloe, Ancud is a city which was visited on 28th June 28, 1834 by Charles Darwin during the Second voyage of HMS Beagle. The population here is rural and survives mainly from fishing. Find out about volunteering on a local farm in this region.

description.web: The Awasi Patagonia is a luxury lodge, which opened in November 2013, made up from 12 luxury villas on a private reserve, just outside Torres del Paine National Park. Built from locally sourced wood and designed to make the most of the views of the park, the villas include fireplace and outdoor hot tub. Private guide and vehicle are provided for tailor made excursions. The lodge also has a restaurant, exclusively for its guests. >> Read more and check availability for the Awasi Patagonia

description.web: Parque Pinguino Rey is a private nature reserve, whose aim is to preseve the colony of king penguins that reside here. It is the only continental king penguin colony. Trips to see the penguins depart from Punta Arenas, 1 or 2 day trips available.

description.web: Found in Corcovado National Park, this unusual part of Patagonia has a flourishing ecosystem that shelters Fiords, bays, rivers, and volcanoes. In Tic-Toc Bay you'll see penguins clustered on small islands, deep blue waters and green forests.

description.web: Chile's most voluminous river, the Baker is famous for its distinctive turquoise blue colour due to glacial sediment. It flows from the enormous General Carrera Lake westwards into the Pacific, reaching the ocean close to the unique and wonderful village of Tortel, a forest village built on stilts. More marvellous photography opportunities await elsewhere with fantastic panoramas all along its course. The Baker River is also nown for fly fishing in particular, as well as the opportunities to descend it by boat. The Baker River is home to an abundance of Rainbow trout, which can be fished from boats or from the riverbanks. The water is crystal clear allowing you to easily observe the trout swimming close by. The Green Baker Lodge is situated by the river and is a comfortable base for fishing and other activities. Unfortunately the Baker is currently under threat from a hydroelectric company. This beautiful river is now home to Conservacion HQ and the Patagonia National Park that the organisation is working hard to create. Find out about volunteering with this organisation on our Volunteer in Patagonia page.

description.web: Tunel Bay is found at the North West corner of Lago Viedma in Los Glaciares National Park. This is one of the last areas you will reach when trekking the Huemul Circuit, and it is possible to get a vehicle transfer from here back to El Chaltén. Boats from here can take you to Glaciar Viedma, and it is possible to fish trout in the bay.

description.web: The Beagle Channel is located in the wild and seemingly inhospitable land of Tierra del Fuego. At it's eastern end, the Beagle Channel forms part of the Chilean-Argentinian border, which was set some hundred years ago. The ownership of the Beagle's three small islands has long been in dispute, but the issue was resolved when the islands were awarded to Chile in 1985.The Beagle Channel is where many Antarctic cruises set sail on their way from the port of Ushuaia all the way down to the South Shetland Islands.It's also a challenging but fun place for kayaking. Kayaking trips tend to focus around Gable Island, where you can paddle to come face to face with sea lion colonies, see penguin rookeries and, if you're lucky, spot whales. Nearby natural landmarks include Mount Darwin, Tierra del Fuego's greatest peak that many climbers attempt to ascend, and Cape Horn. The Beagle Channel's nearest entry point on the Argentinian side is the small port town of Ushuaia, near to where Darwin would have stayed when he visited Tierra del Fuego on board the HMS Beagle in 1831.

description.web: Buenos Aires, the Argentine capital, is where many visitors to the Argentinian part of Patagonia start their trip. Airports Flights from around the world come into the international airport (EZE) just to the South of the city, and the more central domestic airport (AEP) connects Buenos Aires to several airports in Patagonia. We've put together a guide so you can find out about moving between the two airports for connections and what to do in the city while youre there! Things to do The city itself is exciting and vibrant, with plenty of history and sights to discover you'll never be stuck for something to do! Swoop has put together some recommendations of things to do in Buenos Aires, be sure to take a look so you don't miss out!! Accommodation From somewhere to stay for those with a tighter budget to somewhere a bit more special, there are plenty of accommodation offers in Buenos Aires. We have put together a list of our favourites so you can make the most of your stay! Hotels in Buenos Aires >>

description.web: The largest area of protection in Chile, 35 000 square km. It's neighboured by Torres del Paine and Los Glaciares to its east, the two most popular national parks of Patagonia; and San Rafael National Park to its north. The main gateways to the park are Puerto Natales, Villa O'Higgins, and Tortel. It is one of the few homes left for the Patagonian Huemul. Marine otters and Andean condors are also frequently sighted here.

description.web: About the Glacier An impressive hanging glacier, it can be found in the southern part of Torres del Paine National Park in Chilean Patagonia - Patagonia's most popular. Unlike other glaciers in this part of Patagonia, this glacier does not come down off the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap, but is attached to the similar Serrano Glacier. How to see it: Few people visit this impressive glacier whilst in Torres del Paine in comparison to the number of people that hike to the sprawling Glacier Grey whilst trekking the W Circuit. Kayaking A fantastic way of seeing this glacier is kayaking out of the park on a 2 or 3-day tour of the Rio Serrano and its surrouding picturesque area.Find out more about kayaking in Torres del Paine, and kayaking to glaciers. More Details >>

description.web: San Carlos de Bariloche, which comes from the indigenous word 'Vuriloche' meaning "people from behind the mountain", lies on the edge of Lago Nahuel Huapi, a vast, blue lake which is popular with sea-kayakers. Bariloche is the gateway to the Argentinian lake district. Things to do in Bariloche For those looking for some adventure in the winter months, we'd recommend Bariloche's ski resort of Cerro Catedral, 7 miles from town. For some white water rafting, try the Rio Manso which has two sections; Manso Inferior and Manso de la Frontera. Manso Inferior is grade 2-3 and needs about 8 hours to raft. Manso de la Frontera is grade 3-4 and could take a few days to raft. Bariloche's luxury spas and hotels in the hills surrounding the town make the perfect base for day hikes into the Nahuel Huapi National Park (15 miles away in the north-eastern corner of the lake) and for longer mountain biking expeditions. Bariloche's glut of chocolate shops and its sandy beaches attract hoards of Argentinians in the summer months looking to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. The 'Circuito Chico' offers a leisurely trek and bus ride to spectacular viewpoints just outside Bariloche and, although quite touristy, the circuit is worth doing, in particular taking the ski lift up to the Cerro Campanario viewpoint for spectacular vistas of lakes Trebol and Moreno. Find our more about what to do in Bariloche. Accommodation Whether you want to stay in the middle of the town, or if you want to get out to a lake-side lodges or working estancia, there are plenty of options for you in Bariloche and the surrounding Lake District. Take a look at our list of recommended accommodation in the Lake District.
description.quote: San Carlos de Bariloche, which comes from the indigenous word 'Vuriloche' meaning "people from behind the mountain", lies on the edge of Lago Nahuel Huapi, a vast, blue lake which is popular with sea-kayakers. Bariloche is the gateway to the Argentinian lake district. Things to do in Bariloche For those looking for some adventure in the winter months, we'd recommend Bariloche's ski resort of Cerro Catedral, 7 miles from town. For some white water rafting, try the Rio Manso which has two sections; Manso Inferior and Manso de la Frontera. Manso Inferior is grade 2-3 and needs about 8 hours to raft. Manso de la Frontera is grade 3-4 and could take a few days to raft. Bariloche's luxury spas and hotels in the hills surrounding the town make the perfect base for day hikes into the Nahuel Huapi National Park (15 miles away in the north-eastern corner of the lake) and for longer mountain biking expeditions. Bariloche's glut of chocolate shops and its sandy beaches attract hoards of Argentinians in the summer months looking to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. The 'Circuito Chico' offers a leisurely trek and bus ride to spectacular viewpoints just outside Bariloche and, although quite touristy, the circuit is worth doing, in particular taking the ski lift up to the Cerro Campanario viewpoint for spectacular vistas of lakes Trebol and Moreno. Find our more about what to do in Bariloche. Accommodation Whether you want to stay in the middle of the town, or if you want to get out to a lake-side lodges or working estancia, there are plenty of options for you in Bariloche and the surrounding Lake District. Take a look at our list of recommended accommodation in the Lake District.

description.web: If you'd like to stay in private accommodation rather than a hotel, Aires del Fitz, with views of Mount Fitz Roy, are the best place in El Chaltén. They offer comfortable and warm accommodation, with a bedroom upstairs and living room, kitchen and extra bed downstairs for a reasonable price. In the heart of Chaltén and only a 10 minute drive from the start of the trails into Los Glaciares National Park, you can't fault the hospitality of the family that runs them and the accommodation. Find out more and see other hotels in El Chaltén.

description.web: A beautiful spot some 77km from Puerto Piramides in Peninsula Valdes (a UNESCO World Heritage Site), Caleta Valdes lies on the coast of Argentina. Made up of a long, pebbled beach, Caleta Valdes is home to Elephant seals who arrive here in August and spend the following months creating their harem of females. Perhaps the most exciting thing about Caleta Valdes is the opportunity to see Orcas (Killer Whales) hunting seals by purposefully beaching themselves in order to catch their prey between September and April.

description.web: Cabo San Pio lighthouse is located on the Mitre Peninsula in Tierra del Fuego. The area is visited by trekkers and, if the weather is good, they can walk to the cape.

description.web: Caleta Tortel sits on the Rio Baker, with snow capped mountains in the background. A quaint experience, Tortel is essentially a small settlement built on stilts - there are no conventional streets, only raised wooden walkways. It stretches for a couple of kilometres along the shoreline of a cove, sitting amid mountain channels, fjords, estuaries and islands... It's an absolute must if you find yourself in the area. The nearby Steffens and Jorge Montt glaciers can be explored by boat, as can the Isla de los Muertos - the "Island of the Dead" - home to dozens of unnamed graves from the early 20th Century ...and, eerily, nothing else!

description.web: This fjord is a truly specatcular place in which to see huge hanging glaciers coming down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap. The fjord is usually accessed by boat, where passengers disembark onto a Zodiac boat and spend a couple of hours sailing close to the Capitan Constantino, visiting Fernando, Capitan Constantino and Alipio Glaciers amongst others. Find out more about seeing the Calvo Fjord on an adventure cruise in Patagonia >>

description.web: Campamento Britanico is a campsite at the top of the French Valley (Valle Frances), which is used as a base for the few people who climb Las Torres. On the W Trek and Full Circuit, most people trek to this campsite and back, but don't spend a night there. It is around a 30 minute trek from here on to the French Valley Lookout Point, from which there are incredible views of the hanging Glaciar Frances.

description.web: Cape Horn, or Cabo de Hornos, is the southernmost headland of the Tierra del Fuego archipelago and many people aim to see it on their visit to the southernmost city in the world, Ushuaia. In fact, certain Patagonian cruises allow you to visit Cape Horn as part of an adventure through the fjords and channels of Southern Patagonia. It's perhaps best known for the treacherous waters which surround it. Owing to gusty winds, huge waves, strong currents and icebergs, a fair few ships have met there end here over the years The Cape has its own small Hornos Island and the Cape itself marks the northern boundary of the Drake Passage, a notoriously rough body of water separating the southernmost tip of Patagonia from Antarctica.

rows.component_name: Canadon del Rio de las Vueltas

description.web: Rio de las Vueltas literally means 'The Meandering River', and it twists and turns through Los Glaciares National Park, past the town of El Chaltén. A 6km walk or drive to the South East of Chaltén takes you to a view point beside the Rio de las Vueltas Canyon. There are extensive views back along the river to El Chaltén and Mount Fitz Roy behind. From here you can also see the interesting rock strata that make up the canyon walls and can often spot low-flying condors.

description.web: Situated in the flatter and more gentle northeastern part of Torres del Paine National Park, Camping Seron is one of the stops on the Full Circuit and is approximately 5 hours north of the entrance at Laguna Armarga and Refugio Torres. It is about a further 6 hours hike from Dickson Valley. Find out more about hiking the Full Circuit in Torres del Paine >>

description.web: Literally meaning beach, La Playita is a remote campsite on the rocky shore of Lago Electrico and, with towering peaks on either side, this is a very dramatic spot to camp. There are no facilities here other than a few piles of rocks to provide shelter from the wind. Usually this campsite is used to stop off en route to the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap, but there are also other trekking routes to explore in the area. More about Trekking in the Area >>

description.web: Castro is the largest town on Chiloé island and also the oldest: the conquistador and royal governor of Chile Martín Ruiz de Gamboa founded a settlement on the quiet estuary here in 1567 to serve as a base to conquer the island’s Huilliche people. The town is famous for its shingle-roofed palafitos (waterfront stilt houses), which give it a much more attractive air than when a young Charles Darwin passed through in 183 and judged it a forlorn and depressing town. Today, it’s the island’s thriving capital and an important centre for Chile’s salmon industry.Castro’s most famous attraction today is the Iglesia San Francisco de Castro – one of the 16 wooden Chilote churches that make up the island’s UNESCO World Heritage listing. While many of Chiloé's churches can be rather plain in their beauty thanks to their Jesuit roots, the Franciscan church has an exuberant riot of colour covering its neo-Gothic twin-towered exterior. It was built in 1912 to replace its predecessor which had burned to the ground, and hides its iron frame in brightly painted alerce wood, with buttery yellows offset by mauve and violet details. The interior is plainer, with richly polished wood everywhere. Just south of Castro is a second prominent church, Iglesia Nuestra Señora de Gracia de Nercon , with a tall tower easily spotted from the road. Castro has two diverting museums: the Musei Regional de Castro on the main square, which has fine displays dedicated to the original Huillipihe inhabitants, and the Museo de Arte Moderno de Chiloé , which brings the island’s story up to date by showing off Chiloés burgeoning arts scene. Castro’s Mocupulli airport (code MHC) is 20km north of the town and has daily flights to Santiago, which take just under two hours.

The town is famous for its shingle-roofed palafitos (waterfront stilt houses), which give it a much more attractive air than when a young Charles Darwin passed through in 183 and judged it a forlorn and depressing town. Today, it’s the island’s thriving capital and an important centre for Chile’s salmon industry.Castro’s most famous attraction today is the Iglesia San Francisco de Castro – one of the 16 wooden Chilote churches that make up the island’s UNESCO World Heritage listing. While many of Chiloé's churches can be rather plain in their beauty thanks to their Jesuit roots, the Franciscan church has an exuberant riot of colour covering its neo-Gothic twin-towered exterior. It was built in 1912 to replace its predecessor which had burned to the ground, and hides its iron frame in brightly painted alerce wood, with buttery yellows offset by mauve and violet details. The interior is plainer, with richly polished wood everywhere. Just south of Castro is a second prominent church, Iglesia Nuestra Señora de Gracia de Nercon , with a tall tower easily spotted from the road. Castro has two diverting museums: the Musei Regional de Castro on the main square, which has fine displays dedicated to the original Huillipihe inhabitants, and the Museo de Arte Moderno de Chiloé , which brings the island’s story up to date by showing off Chiloés burgeoning arts scene. Castro’s Mocupulli airport (code MHC) is 20km north of the town and has daily flights to Santiago, which take just under two hours.

description.web: Located in the Magellan Strait, Carlos III Island is close by the Francisco Coloane Maritime Park, a protected coastal area of some 67,000 acres, for scientific research. It's here that it's possible to see Humpback whales breaching and playing in the water during a Patagonian Adventure Cruise from December through to April.

description.web: The Capillas de Marmol (the Marble Caves), also known as Catderal de Marmol (the Marble Cathedral), is an inredible natural attraction that draws hundreds of visitors every year to the little town of Puerto Tranquilo (from where boats and kayaks can be rented with which to visit). Created by the erosive effect of the blue water of Lago General Carrera lapping at the stone, the Cathedral looks like a beautiful piece of sculpted artwork.

description.web: Cerro Bandera or Flag Mountain in the Chilean part of Tierra del Fuego has a well-known reasonably easy trekking route which leads you up the valley to the mountain. From the top you have panoramic views over the town of Puerto Williams and The Beagle Channel. It takes about half a day to trek up and down and once you reach the top of Cerro Bandera it is commonplace to place a stone to show you were there.

description.web: Aconcagua is one of the '7 summits' - the highest peak in each continent. In fact it's the highest mountain in both the Western and Southern Hemispheres. And yet, it is accessible to amateurs - fit, strong and resolute amateurs, but amateurs nevertheless. This is your chance to don the crampons and ice axe, feel the exhilaration of climbing above the clouds, and earn the right to say that you've climbed one of the '7 summits'. More info on climbing Mount Aconcagua

description.web: Cerro Benítez is a prominent mountain peak in Chilean Patagonia, located near Puerto Natales, known for its scenic hiking trails that offer panoramic views of the surrounding landscapes, including Lago Sofía, and for its significant archaeological sites with ancient cave paintings, as well as being a prime location for spotting Andean condors. It is also geologically linked to the Cueva del Milodón Natural Monument, which sits on its southern flank.

description.web: See this striking mountain as you make your way along the Rio Manso by raft! At this point along the river, you'll have a fantastic view of Mount Bastión, as you head along a narrow canyon. Reminiscent of Los Cuernos in Torres del Paine due to its colours and shape, Cerro Bastión is located in the beautiful Nahuel Huapi National Park in the Patagonian Lake District of Argentina.

description.web: Cerro Castillo is a small farming settlement in southern Chilean Patagonia, not far from the larger town of Puerto Natales. Cerro Castillo is one of the landmarks on many horse riding trips in southern Patagonia as it evokes the 'estancia' lifestyle of this region. The fact that Cerro Castillo lies on the open pampas makes it a great base from which to go horse riding and gives you incredible views of Torres del Paine National Park in the distance. With regard to amenities, there isn't much save for a cafe (which does a very nice lamb soup) and shop with lots of books, clothes and goodies for tourists. The bus from Puerto Natales into Torres del Paine stops here en route. As does the bus from El Calafate, so on some trekking trips into Torres del Paine you can start from Calafate and join your group here at lunchtime, and head directly into the park that afternoon. For example this guided W Trek. More info on getting to Torres del Paine.

description.web: This mountain takes its name from its location, in the corner of the Paine Grande mountain range. Standing at some 1750 metres, it's one of the overlooked peaks of Torres del Paine but certainly a very impressive mountain. If you're hiking the W Circuit or Full Circuit in Torres del Paine, you're unlikely to get near it, but some operators offer off the beaten track trips which allow you to climb part way up the mountain.

description.web: Mount Donoso stands at 1,332m and is visible from the beautiful Rio Serrano in the South of the park. From its lookout, you can see out over Torres del Paine National Park, one of the gems of Patagonia. It's also one of the highlights of many horse riding trips in this area of Patagonia, which allow you to ride like a gaucho across the open pampas.

description.web: Cerro Falkner (2350m) is located in Nahuel Napi National Park. The ascent through nire and lenga woods takes about 3 hours and is of a medium-level difficulty. You may see condors, foxes and ducks along the way. On reaching the summit ridge, you will be rewarded with mesmerising views of Villarino and Filo Hua Hun lakes, as well as the snow-capped peak of Lanín Volcano.

description.web: Gorra Blanca is a 2,900m peak on the eastern edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap , marking the border between Chile and Argentina. Whilst this isn't technically demanding it is a challenging expedition of 5 to 7 days, approaching over glaciers and the Ice Cap itself, with a thousand metre ascent on summit day.The mountain, which was first climbed in 1964, presents great views over the Ice Cap (to the West) and out to Argentina (to the East).Typically, you'd base yourself in El Chaltén in Argentina, approach via the Rio Electrico and Piedra del Fraile and use La Playita as your basecamp. From there you head up the Marconi Glacier and over the Marconi Pass.Swoop Founder and CEO, Luke, attempted to climb Gorra Blanca in January 2011, but unfortunately the weather conditions only allowed his group to reach the Marconi Pass.

description.web: Cerro Guido is located in Patagonia, Chile. At the base is an estancia, used as a starting point for treks to the summit. On the summit itself is a native Indian burial mound.

description.web: Cerro Fitz Roy is named after the Captain of the HMS Beagle, who came to Patagonia in 1834 with Charles Darwin. The mountain is a 3,375m towering spire of rock and ice and it is recognised as one of the great challenges by the world's climbing community. It is also known as "Cerro Chaltén" or "smoking mountain". Where is it? Fitz Roy sits on the Chile-Argentina border and stands out quite visibly as you fly over the Ice Cap It is situated in Los Glaciares (The Glaciers) National Park, near to El Chaltén - it dominates the view from this small town on a clear day How to see it: The best views can be found either by: Hiking to Laguna de los Tres on a day-hike from El Chaltén, or trekking the longer Huemul Circuit Or, for the more adventurous, trekking out onto the South Patagonian Ice Cap and viewing it from the west How to get there: A popular trekking destination, it is served by the hotels of El Chaltén and the airport in El Calafate, just a four-hour bus ride away Alternatively, consider a trekking tour combining Los Glaciares, in Argentina, and Torres del Paine, in Chile For another way to explore Patagonia, check out our road tours

description.web: Cerro Mojon Rojo is a peak close to Mount Fitz Roy in Los Glaciares National Park. This mountain can be climbed in two days and the ascent is semi-technical, including a glacier crossing. From the summit there are spectacular views of the massifs of both Cerro Torre and Fitz Roy. Find out More about Trekking in Los Glaciares >>

description.web: Cerro Moreno is the third highest peak in Patagonia and is rarely climbed. It is the highest peak in the Cordon Mariano Moreno massif, which lies to the West of the South Patagonian Ice Cap and is accessible only by a lengthy trek over the ice. Trekking the Patagonian Ice Cap >>

description.web: Cerro Paine Grande is the highest summit of the Cordillera Paine Mountain Range in Torres del Paine National Park. Paine Grande stands at 2750 metres, closely followed by the Cuerno Principal which is said to reach some 2600 metres. You can get great views and photo opportunities of Cerro Paine from across Lago Pehoé and from the area around Refugio Paine Grande, a comfortable hostal on the north-west corner of Lago Pehoé. This is one of the key peaks you will hike around when trekking the Full Circuit or the W Circuit.

description.web: Standing at some 1,508 metres, Cerro Paine is a notable peak in the east of the Paine massif and one of the few that is accessible to trekkers. If you trek the Full Circuit rather than the W Trek then you'll be able to see Cerro Paine, but you won't be climbing it. You'll need to get off the beaten track with a private guide to climb up here.

description.web: An impressive peak in Tierra del Fuego, Cerro Pelado stands at 930 feet and, from its summit, trekkers can look out over the whole of Ushuaia and beyond to the Beagle Channel. The perfect place for a day hike, Mount Pelado is easily accessed from Ushuaia with the help of a local guide. Find out more about trekking in Tuerra del Fuego from Ushuaia.

description.web: Cerro Zapata (1590m/5,220ft) is located in Torres del Paine National Park. It is possible to climb to the summit on a 26km day hike from Zapata camp.

description.web: Monte San Lorenzo (3,706m) is a mountain on the Argentinian and Chilean border. The peak was first climbed in 1943. It gained notoriety in 2014 when professional skiers JP Auclair and Andreas Fransson died on its slopes in an avalanche.

description.web: Cerro Toco is a dormant stratovolcano in the Atacama Desert of northern Chile, known for being one of the most accessible high-altitude peaks in the region and a popular destination for acclimatization hikes with panoramic views of the surrounding volcanoes and salt flats.
description.quote: Cerro Toco is a dormant stratovolcano in the Atacama Desert of northern Chile, known for being one of the most accessible high-altitude peaks in the region and a popular destination for acclimatization hikes with panoramic views of the surrounding volcanoes and salt flats.

description.web: Cerro Solo stands beside Laguna Torre in the same range as Cerro Torre. The ascent involves crossing a glacier after a difficult climb over loose rock, but this is the least technical climb out of the mountains in this range. From the peak, you get unparalleled views of Cerro Torre and Fitz Roy, as well as the South Patagonian Ice Field.Find out more about Trekking in Los Glaciares or Trekking the Ice Cap.

description.web: Standing close to Cerro Fitz Roy, on the edge of the South Patagonian Ice Field, Cerro Torre stands at 3,102 metres. This is one of the highest peaks in the region, and it is a very challenging one to climb. Shrouded in controversial claims of ascent, the first undisputed ascent was in 1974. Where is it? Cerro Torre stands amid the peaks, glaciers, rivers and lagoons of Los Glaciares (The Glaciers) National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site Close to the Patagonian mountain village of El Chaltén, and 4 hours by bus from the airport of El Calafate How to see it: Many of the treks from El Chaltén take you to view-points of Cerro Torre and Cerro Fitz Roy, including several day-hikes, as well longer routes, such as the Huemul Circuit How to get there: Staying in the nearby town of El Chaltén, there are many day-hikes which give you great views of Cerro Torre There is a much more challenging route which takes you up onto the Ice Cap to get much closer to the mountain and see it from a different angle, as part of a demanding expedition You could also make it part of a trekking tour, combining the peaks and glaciers of Los Glaciares with the equally stunning landscapes of Torres del Paine National Park in Chile

description.web: At 4058m, this is the highest mountain in Chilean Patagonia. It is also know as Mount San Clemente. It is climbable, but it is a long ascent and is prone to bad weather. We wouldn't recommend it unless you have prior experience of such difficult climbs.

description.web: Located next to Lago del Desierto, to the North of El Chaltén, Cerro Vespignani is arguably the best peak in the area which can be climbed in just one day. The climb is not overly technical, and from the top there are magnificient views of the South Patagonian Ice Field.

description.web: Chillán Nuevo is one of the three main volcanic cones within the Nevados de Chillán Volcanic Complex, an active group of stratovolcanoes in the Andes of the Ñuble Region, Central Chile. This dome complex was formed between 1906 and 1945 and is known for its ongoing volcanic activity. 3,212 m (10,538 ft)

description.web: A small town on the southern shore of the Lago Genereal Carrera, it is one of the largest of the surrounding settlements. Just 4km west of the border with Argentina, it serves as a nice little stop-over when crossing between Chile and Argentina. Crossing the lake by ferry to Puerto Ibanez on the north shore is a lovely experience in the summer sun, as is following the route along the shoreline by car.

description.web: The Chepu River Valley is located on the west coast of Chiloé Island.
description.quote: The Chepu River Valley is located on the west coast of Chiloé Island.

description.web: Chiloé is a truly unique location. Its vast coastline, wetlands, river systems, forests and fields offer some of the richest bird watching in Southern Chile; even from the 30 minute ferry journey to access the island, you can spot dolphins, penguins and groups of playful sea lions. On arrival on the island you will be met with rolling countryside, dramatic coastal scenery, quiet bays and inlets, and allwith a back drop of the mighty snow peaked Andes. Get off the beaten track for a few days hiking the rugged pacific coast, sea kayak in the peaceful water channels, visit penguin colonies and explore beautiful wooden Jesuit churches on the Eastern Coast. More about Chiloe >>

description.web: This revolutionary winery is solely dedicated to the production of Casa Lapostolle's world-class icon wine, Clos Apalta. The winery is 100% gravity-fed spanning five levels, three of which are buried into the granite of the Apalta hillside to provide a natural cool temperature environment for cellaring and ageing.

description.web: Chorrillo del Salto is a waterfall with a drop of around 20 metres, which can be reached by a 3km walk from El Chaltén. The waterfall is hidden in a lenga forest and the area around it is a great place to relax on a fine day. In the winter months, it freezes over completely and is popular with ice climbers.

description.web: Camp Confluencia is around a 4 hour hike (normally taken at a very steady pace) from the entrance to the Aconcagua Provincial Park. It's not quite as large as Plaza de Mulas and has fewer services but it's well established with several mess tents and very basic toilet facilities. Confluencia is normally the base for an acclimatisation day to Plaza Francia along the eastern edge of the 10km long Horcones glacier ( Ventisquero Horcones Inferior). From Confluencia the route up to basecamp is via the Horcones valley, and normally an 8-9 hour day.

description.web: The spot to go to see sea lion colonies in the wild. Jump in a kayak and find yourself literally metres from them. You'll also see snow-capped peaks and lush forests with native trees including the famous Chilean alerce. You'll see plunging waterfalls, granite slopes dropping into the water and get the chance to relax in one of this regions many natural springs.

description.web: Cochrane is the base for many adventures into the Aisen region of Chile. It is the provincial capital of Prat Province and one of the main and most comprehensvie supply and service centres to the south of Chile Chico. Tamango National Reserve, designed for the conservation of South Andean Deer, lies nearby and also offers fishing trips and long walks suitable for all ages. For the mountaineers among you, Mt San Lorenzo (3, 706m) - one of the highest peaks in Patagonia, is accessible from the town.

description.web: The town of Cochamo is a wonderful base for a range of activities in the area. Mountain biking, trekking and horse riding are great ways to see this verdant region, as you cross rivers, visit waterfalls and ride through dense rainforest on your way up to La Junta Valley. This remote place east of the Reloncaví Estuary holds lots of lakes for kayaking in Cochamo, if you fly in from Puerto Varas or Puerto Montt you can be kayaking on Lake Tagua Tagua only a few hours later. More about Cochamo >>

description.web: The Cordoba Pass (1311m) is located on Route 63, between Lake Traful and Lake Filo Hua Hum. It is a popular destination for cyclists.

description.web: The Cordillera de la Sal (Salt Mountain Range) is a unique geological formation near San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, composed of salt, clay, and gypsum that have been sculpted by wind and water into surreal, Martian-like landscapes and canyons.

description.web: The Darwin range lies in the Chilean part of Tierra del Fuego, and offers the chance to trek in a remote and impressive landscape. The highest mountain in the range is Monte Darwin, which is a challenging peak to climb.

description.web: Conguillío National Park is a stunning national park in the Araucanía Region of Chile, famous for its otherworldly, volcanic landscapes dominated by the active Llaima volcano, ancient forests of "monkey puzzle" trees (araucaria), and beautiful lakes and lagoons formed by lava flows.

description.web: Where to find them Torres del Paine National Park, Chile What are they? The Cuernos del Paine or 'Paine horns' is a collective name given to a set of spiky granite peaks in Torres del Paine National Park , all of which stand at over 2000 metres high. The spikes have fittingly sharp names: to the north, the Aleta de Tiburón (Shark's Fin), to the east, from north to south, Fortaleza (Fortress), La Espada (The Sword), La Hoja (The Blade), La Máscara (The Mask), Cuerno Norte (North Horn), and Cuerno Principal (Main Horn).The Cuernos del Paine also lend their name to one of the park's 'refugios' or 'lodges', Refugio and Camping Los Cuernos . How can I see them? The Cuernos are located in the middle of the W Trek, the most popular route for trekking in Torres del Paine National Park. Best views are from the top of Valle Frances, often hiked on day 3 of a traditional W Trek. Find out more about... Hiking in Torres del Paine The W Trek Getting to Torres del Paine

description.web: The Cordillera Baguales are lesser-explored range of mountains in Patagonia, Chile. There are stunning views of Torres del Paine from the summit.

description.web: Coyhaique is a provincial and regional capital, known for its interesting pentagonal design. It is also key access point into Patagonia and onto the Carretera Austral, the magical route that connects northern Chile to its southern wilderness. The airport at Balmaceda is just 55km away, making this the perfect first stop at which to get your bearings once you land. It's a sizeable city for the region, home to 55 000 people, and has all of the necessities you might expect. Positioned on the confluence of the Simpson and Coyhaique Rivers, it is a great place for fly-fishing.

description.web: The Cueva de las Manas (Cave of the Hands) is one of the most important archaeological sites in South America. The cave paintings date from between 9300 to 3300 years ago and were made by the ancestors of the Tehuelche people. The site was declared a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1999.

description.web: The small coastal town of Dalcahue is one of the best places on Chiloé for handicrafts shopping: its Sunday market attracts artisans from across the island to sell their wares. Woollen goods including jumpers, hats and chunky socks, all hand-dyed with natural pigments make the best souvenirs here. If you can’t make it on a Sunday, a smaller version of the market runs throughout the week. Chile’s 1960 earthquake saw the destruction of most of Dalcahue’s palafitos (waterfront stilt houses), but the town’s most important traditional wooden church survived the tremor. The Iglesia de Nuestra Señora de los Dolores (Church of Our Lady of Sorrows) with its nine-arched facade, octagonal bell tower and interior barrel roof in simple whitewash was built in 1849, and is one of the 16 churches that collectively won Chiloé its UNESCO World Heritage-listed status in 2015. From Dalcahue, it’s possible to take a short ferry trip across the channel to Quinchao Island , where you can visit the equally imposing Iglesia Santa María de Loreto , Chiloés oldest church, built by the Jesuits in 1740.

description.web: Death Valley (Valle de la Muerte) is a desert valley near San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, known for its surreal, Mars-like landscape of jagged rock formations and massive sand dunes, making it a popular spot for sandboarding and watching the sunset

description.web: Diablo Lake and Hill are located in the Los Glaciares region. The trail in this area is in a private reserve and is one of Chalténs lesser-known gems.

description.web: The Dientes de Navarino or 'Navarino Teeth' located on Navarino Island in the Chilean part of Tierra del Fuego, get their name from the formation of these peaks in a semi circle that resembles a jaw full of teeth. The trail was first discovered in the early 1990's by Australian climber and author, Clem Lindenmayer. Find out more about the trek here. The town of Puerto Williams is the main access point for the trek which can be accessed on a flight from Punta Arenas. The town is very small so provisions are best acquired in Punta Arenas.

description.web: Dickson Lake and Glacier are found in the northern part of the famous Torres del Paine National Park in Chilean Patagonia. Only 5% of visitors to the park come to see the beauty of this valley, which is visited on the Full Circuit trek of Paine as opposed to the W Circuit, which takes in the highlights of Las Torres, Valle Frances and Glacier Grey. Dickson has a campsite and Refugio for trekkers and bikers, who come this way on guided mountain biking tours. To find out more about visiting Lago Dickson, see our Torres del Paine page.

description.web: Monolithic carved human figures stand guard to the majestic Easter Island, where you can experience the natural tropical beauty of beaches, waterfalls, forests and volcanoes. A small town on the island offers peaceful accommodation in a characterful lodge, with gardens filled with hummingbirds and fragrant flowers.

description.web: In the heart of Torres del Paine National Park, the Eco Camp is made up of a collection of geodesic domes, designed to minismise its environmental footprint. The domes provide accommodation ranging from comfortable standard domes with shared bathrooms to luxurious suite domes. A good selection of excursions with English speaking guides are on offer. Find out more about Eco Camp Patagonia.

description.web: A picturesque spot close to Tierra del Fuego National Park, Ensenada Bay offers 'postcard views' over the Beagle Channel with mountains and water as far as the eye can see. Many excursions take you to this area of Tierra del Fuego as part of a day trip to the national park. It's also a popular place to go kayaking as you're likely to see seals and cormorant colonies.

description.web: El Chaltén is a small trekking town in Los Glaciares National Park. From El Chaltén, you can hike straight into the mountains of the Fitz Roy area. Sitting at the foot of Cerro Fitz Roy, which dominates the skyline on a clear day, El Chaltén is the base for the top climbers to tackle this peak, as well as many others, and for expeditions onto the South Patagonian Ice Cap. Accommodation options, restaurants, bars and places to rent or buy gear are all good , but communications with the outside world remain very primitive - a blessing for many visitors.

description.web: If you're planning to visit Los Glaciares National Park, you'll almost certainly pass through El Calafate on the shores of Lago Argentino. With a major airport and easy transport links to other destinations in Argentina, El Calafate is the hub for anyone wanting to visit El Chaltén and Fitz Roy or the Perito Moreno Glacier. The town is also a 5 hour bus journey from Puerto Natales in Chile, the gateway to Torres del Paine National Park.

description.web: Ensenada is on the eastern shore of Lago Llanquihue and 47km from Puerto Varas. From here you can climb the nearby Volcan Osorno which dominates the skyline, or visit the waterfalls of the Petrohué river, just 7km away.

description.web: El Paso León is a remote and historically significant Mountain Pass located on the border between Chile and Argentina, in the Southern Patagonian Ice Field region. It is a challenging trekking route that offers stunning views of glaciers and pristine Patagonian wilderness, often used by experienced adventurers and as a boundary reference point.

description.web: Nearest airport to the Perito Moreno glacier, and the El Chaltén / Mount Fitz Roy area. Daily flights to and from Buenos Aires (AEP). Occasional flights to Bariloche and Ushuaia.

description.web: El Bolson, a bustling tourist town in the Argentinian Lake District is known for its old hippies who came here from Buenos Aires in the 1970s and its local market selling artisan crafts. Located about an hour's drive from the Chilean border, El Bolsón is the closest town to Los Alerces National Park and is found in the southwest of Río Negro Province, Argentina. Although there isn't an infinite number of things to do in the centre of El Bolsón, it is a nice place for a stroll and an ice cream, particularly when the weather is warm during Patagonian summer (Nov-March). El Bolsón is a only 1.5 hour's drive from Bariloche, and is a popular place from which to go trekking, horse riding, fly fishing and kayaking into the surrounding mountains, lakes and rivers.

description.web: Located in the Aysen region of Chile, El Mirador de Guadal is the ideal lodge for you to discover the southern part of the Carretera Austral. Situated on the southern border of Lake General Carrera all our rooms have a unique view of the turquoise waters of the lake and the glaciers of the Northern Ice Field

description.web: A private, family-owned estancia located to the north of Lanín National Park - the most secluded and scenic part of the Patagonia Lake District in Argentina. Offer the ultimate horseback riding, polo, and fly fishing experiences in Northern Patagonia.

description.web: Surrounded by mountains and plains, this remote, upscale, seasonal, all-inclusive hotel is 7km from Lago Argentino lake, and 27km from the nearest town, El Calafate. Airy, upscale suites are TV-free and offer mountain, valley and/or lake views. All have free Wi-Fi. Meals, guided hikes, mountain biking and round-trip transportation from El Calafate are included. Other amenities include a polished restaurant/bar with lake views, a cosy lounge, a TV room and a library. There's also an indoor pool and a sauna. Children age 12 and over are welcome.

description.web: Estancia Harberton is an old farm situated in Tierra del Fuego on the shore of the Beagle Channel. Although no longer keeping sheep, the estancia still raises cattle alongside providing accommodation for visitors from October to April. The estancia is visited on some boat trips from Ushuaia, and there are guides who give guided tours of the farm and the area's oldest Nature Reserve. Harberton was the first estancia established on the island of Tierra del Fuego in 1886. It was brought here from England by Thomas Bridges, a missionary who had come to evangelise the Yaghan peoples who lived there. Thomas Bridges and his family were the first family to live peacefully (apart from one occurence) amongst the Yaghan and the sixth generation of the family still lives there today.
description.quote: Estancia Harberton is an old farm situated in Tierra del Fuego on the shore of the Beagle Channel. Although no longer keeping sheep, the estancia still raises cattle alongside providing accommodation for visitors from October to April. The estancia is visited on some boat trips from Ushuaia, and there are guides who give guided tours of the farm and the area's oldest Nature Reserve. Harberton was the first estancia established on the island of Tierra del Fuego in 1886. It was brought here from England by Thomas Bridges, a missionary who had come to evangelise the Yaghan peoples who lived there. Thomas Bridges and his family were the first family to live peacefully (apart from one occurence) amongst the Yaghan and the sixth generation of the family still lives there today.

description.web: Estancia Cristina provides comfortable accommodation in 5 small lodges at the tip of a northern branch of Lago Argentino. The estancia is close to the spectacular Glaciar Upsala, which can be seen on a variety of excursions, including boat trips on the lake. Horse riding, trekking, fishing and 4x4 trips are all offered by the estancia.

description.web: Esquel is a small welsh settlement town, located in the Chubut Province of Argentina. The Esquel Airport (EQS) is an international airport serving this area. This town acts as a gateway to the Los Alerces National Park, which is approximately 30 miles away. Here there are opportunities to take some wonderful boat trips on the lakes or to explore on foot with some lovely walking routes. Find out more about places to go in Argentina >>

description.web: Experience the authentic estancia lifestyle of Patagonia in this beautifully rugged and remote setting. The main concern of the estancia is raising cattle and horses, and this is the perfect base for incredible horse-riding experiences. Other activities, including fly fishing, are also on offer here, and at the end of each adventure-filled day you can relax with traditional wine and asado. Find out more about Estancia Huechahue.

description.web: An authentic estancia on the outskirts of El Chaltén. If you're looking for an interesting place to stay, with comfortable rooms and huge beds, bright and welcoming dining room and library, plus an out house which is part of the old estancia, you'll find it here. The Halvorsen family that live here are descended from one of the original settlers in Chaltén. Find out more and see other hotels in El Chaltén.

description.web: Laguna Amarga is one of the best places on earth to observe pumas in the wild. Nowhere else the population density is as high as on this Ranch. Previously it was common practice for the land owners to hunt pumas, in order to avoid that those kill their sheep. Now however, there has grown a new generation on the Estancias, advocating for a tolerant cooperation. Now you can watch the pumas in their natural habitat while on the same Estancia there is being practiced livestock farming, whereupon the sheep are being guarded by livestock guardian dogs, so that they don’t fall prey to the pumas.

description.web: Estancia Perales, a remote waterside estancia, is almost next to the Glaciar Serrano, a beautiful hanging glacier in the southern part of Torres del Paine National Park. Dominated by the high peaks of the Chacabuco mountain range, some of which are permanently covered in snow and ice, and with views of Cerro Prat to the rear, this is a very special place and a real contrast to some of the scenery inside the Park. The estancia welcomes a variety of guests who arrive here either via Zodiac boat from Puerto Natales or on the 21 de Mayo boat which collects kayakers from further up the Serrano River. The estancia is not only a great place for a lamb asado, it also farms cattle and sheep.

description.web: Estancia Puerto Consuelo is a historic Patagonian ranch and tourist attraction located near Puerto Natales in Chilean Patagonia. It is notable as the site of the first permanent European settlement in the Ultima Esperanza province, founded by German pioneer Hermann Eberhard, and offers visitors an authentic experience of Patagonian life, including traditional lamb barbecues (asado al palo) and activities like horseback riding along the Eberhard Fjord.

description.web: Glaciar Jorge Montt is a massive tidewater glacier located in the Bernardo O'Higgins National Park in the Aysén Region of Chilean Patagonia, known for its dramatic retreat in recent decades, which has created a new fjord and made it a key site for observing the effects of climate change.

description.web: The Marconi Glacier lies in the Los Glaciares area around El Chaltén and Fitz Roy. Unsurprisingly, there are many glaciers to be found here... This is one of the most difficult to visit, however, because of the physical and technical intensity of hiking to it - a guide is needed to access it, and also to climb up it. How to see it: Trekking Trekking a thousand metres up the glacier brings you to the Marconi Pass , which is one of only three passes onto the South Patagonian Ice Field. The trek is demanding and should only really be attempted if you’re used to challenging hikes on difficult terrain, but the truly spectacular views over the ice cap from the top make the climb worthwhile. Check out other Patagonian mountaineering opportunities and ice cap expeditions onto the Patagonian ice shelf. More Details >>

description.web: The huge Glaciar Grande is one of the many glaciers in Los Glaciares National Park to come down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap. The glacier, which runs into the pale Laguna Torre, is relatively easily accessible. The trek up to the glacier from El Chaltén is an enjoyable one which leads you along the picturesque Rio Fitz Roy, which, like the famous Mount Fitz Roy, is named after the captain of the HMS Beagle on Darwin's voyage through Patagonia. It's possible to don a pair of crampons and ice hike on this impressive glacier, but only with a guide. From here you'll have spectacular views to the north of the long glacial tongue of Glacier Torre and Cerro Torre standing at some 3,102 metres.

description.web: Coming down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap, Glaciar Geike is reasonably difficult to access by any other means than kayak. This impressive glacier has been retreating for the last few years and doesn't see any signs of slowing down. Find out more about visiting this glacier on our kayaking in Torres del Paine page.

description.web: Glaciar Piedras Blancas is in the Los Glaciares National Park and is sometimes referred to as Glaciar Fitz Roy Este. It is a highly popular viewpoint when trekking this region. How to see it: Hiking It is possible to do a day’s hike taking in both this glacier and the nearby Laguna de Los Tres. The laguna is probably the most famous and most popular viewpoint for Mt. Fitz Roy, and as it is a relatively easy hike up to the laguna, do not expect any solitude. The view is magnificent, including "Los Tres", the three peaks that you can see from the laguna's shore: Fitz Roy (3,405m), Poincenot (3,002m), and Saint-Exupéry (2,558m).

description.web: About the Glacier: Known as the Great Glacier , Galciar O'Higgins is one of the largest in the Southern Hemisphere. This truly spectacular glacier is part of the Southern Patagonian Ice Field, coming down into the remote Chilean Patagonian area of Aisen - home to the legendary Carretera Austral highway How to see it: Road Trip Glaciar O'Higgins is part of the natural roadblock that arises at the village of Villa O'Higgins, marking the terminus of the Carretera Austral - a highway that makes up the spine of Chile, connecting the isolated communities in the Patagonian wilderness to the developed north of the country. Boat Once at Villa O'Higgins, you'll have to take a boat out onto Lago O'Higgins, touring the various glaciers that feed into it. From the boat, you can either reurn to Villa O'Higgins to continue northwards or stay at a nearby luxury lodge; or cross into Argentinean Patagonia, heading towards Lago del Desierto's Aguas Arriba Lodge and the hiking community of El Chaltén. More Details >>

description.web: Glaciar Martial lies just a few kilometres away from the city of Ushuaia, and can be reached by trekking, in contrast to most glaciers in this area which can only by accessed by boat. The glacier is 1,050 metres above sea level, affording some great views for those who climb up to it, and it is possible to undertake ice-hiking on the glacier. In the winter, a ski resort opens here, and there is a chairlift to make the ascent easier.

description.web: Part of Patagonia's most popular national park - Torres del Paine - Glaciar Tyndall is fed by the South Patagonian Ice Cap - one of the largest sub-polar masses of ice in the world. It sits adjacent to Glaciar Zapata and feeds into Glaciar Geike and Lago Tyndall. How to see it: Kayaking Kayakers can see the Tyndall glacier by paddling along the Rio Serrano from the south of Torres del Paine and camping nearby on the river bank.Find out more about kayaking in Torres del Paine and kayaking to glaciers.

description.web: Where to find it Torres del Paine National Park, Chile What is it? The Grey Glacier is one of Torres del Paine's most spectacular glaciers, and tumbles into the serene Lago Grey. The Grey Glacier is part of the Southern Patagonian Ice Field, and at its peak is 30 metres high, and around six kilometres wide. How can I see it? Trekking Torres del Paine has two classic multi-day hikes, the Full Circuit and the W Trek, both of which have awe-inspiring views of the lake and the glacier. Arguably the best view comes from during the Full Circuit hike, where trekkers can view the glacier from above as they cross the famous John Garner Pass. The W Trek's western leg takes you along its eastern shore of Lago Grey all the way up to the glacier itself. You can also hike up around the lake on a day hike, returning to a comfortable base in the evening. Boat excursion Those looking for a less demanding view can take a boat trip from the southern shore right up to the glacier. Ice-hiking No experience is necessary to don crampons, grab an ice axe and get out onto the glacier. If you relish an adventure and have never before walked over the top of a glacier, this is a fantastic place to start.After her expedition onto the ice, Swoop's Harriet maintains that 'everyone should add ice hiking onto a trek in Torres del Paine!'. You can read Harriet's Review here. Kayaking Paddle amongst the lake's sculpted icebergs, so close you can reach out and touch them. Find out more about... Torres del Paine National Park Glaciers in Patagonia Hiking in Torres del Paine

description.web: This impressive glacier is found in the pristine Aysen region of southern Patagonian Chile. It is one of the major outlet glaciers of the Northern Patagonian Ice Field and calves into the Laguna San Rafael, within the national park of the same name. The glacier itself is stunning and sailing amongst the huge icebergs on the lake is a thrilling experience. Find out more about visiting Aysen or seeing this glacier on an adventure cruise in Patagonia >>.

description.web: Glaciar Viedma is a gigantic glacier flowing into the western end of Lake Viedma that exists primarily due to the ice that calves off the glacier and melts into the lake. The width of the glacier that touches the lake is about 1.2 miles and stretches back to the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap for many miles. How to see it Ice Trekking and Climbing Ice trekking and ice climbing are both possible on the glacier, which is accessible by a bus and boat trip from El Chaltén - a hikers' haven nestled amid the mountains of Los Glaciares National Park.Find out more about ice-hiking on glaciers and mountaineering in Patagonia.

description.web: About the Glacier Torre Glacier is a reasonably accessible glacier, which is popular with ice hikers. Below the glacier you'll find Laguna Torre which gives you stunning views of the Los Glaciares National Park. At 3,102 metres, Cerro Torre stands above the glacier which, like many other glaciers in the national park, comes down off the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap. How to see it: Trekking Located so close to Cerro Torre, the trekking landmark of Los Glaciares along with Mt. FitzRoy, anyone hiking in the area should definitely make their way to Torre Glacier and its lagoon. More Details >>

description.web: Green Baker Lodge is made up of seven comfortable cabins, all with views of the Baker River. The river is the main attraction of this lodge, being one of the best places to fish rainbow trout. As well as fly fishing, hiking, mountain biking and vehicle-based excursions are possible in the area around the lodge.

description.web: This huge protected gulf on the western side of Peninsula Valdes is a fantastic place for kayaking in the region as the relatively sheltered waters make it a haven for wildlife. In particular colonies of sea lions live here as well as Southern Right Whales who come here to breed and calve in the summer months.

description.web: This is a luxurious lodge offering comfortable rooms and excellent service. The surrounding lakes - General Carrera, Bertrand and Negro - make for a beautiful backdrop to trekking and horseriding, and also give you the opportunity for boat trips and fly fishing.

description.web: Guatín, also known as the Valley of the Cactus (Valle de los Cactus), is a canyon located near San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, where the Puritama and Purifica rivers converge, creating a unique ecosystem that supports a massive population of towering Candelaria cacti, some reaching over seven meters high. It's a popular spot for hiking and exploring the striking desert landscape.

description.web: One of Chile's Famous Vineyards. On these foothills, between 1992 and 1993, one hundred and twenty hectares of vineyards were planted, mainly with the reds Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Carmenère, and the whites Chardonnay and Sauvignon Blanc. Haras de Pirque's name honors the country´s oldest thoroughbred breeding stud, founded in 1892.

description.web: Hotel Cabanas del Paine provides comfortable accommodation at the southern border of Torres del Paine National Park beside Rio Serrano. The hotel's restaurant serves local food and Chilean wine, as well as more elaborate dishes, and there is also a traditional 'quincho' grill. In addition, there is an outdoor hot tub with views of the park.

description.web: This fantastic lodge/hotel has a privileged location next to the Salto Chico waterfall , in the heart of the Torres del Paine National Park. The exclusive service offered by Explora includes a wide range of easy to difficult hikes in the park, to the Towers, Valle Frances and Valle Pingo, amongst others. The hotel also offers exciting half-day and full day rides with Chilean gauchos starting out from its beautifully cared for stables. The hotel's rooms all have views of either the Salto Chico or the impressive curly Cuernos peaks and the hotel also boasts a spa and swimming pool, 3-course meals and an open bar. What more could you ask for? >> More info about Explora Patagonia. >> See more hotels in Torres del Paine.

description.web: This hotel is set high up in the mountains above Ushuaia with unrivalled views of the surrounding channels and jagged peaks. You can hike straight from your hotel deep into the wild mountains of Tierra del Fuego to gain incredible views down onto the Beagle Channel and surrounding peaks. Alternatively, enjoy the spa facilities that the hotel has on offer whilst soaking in the stunning views. Find more information on our hotel page >>

description.web: Hosteria El Paraiso is one of the most popular and friendly places to stay in El Chaltén. With a cosy wood burning stove in the dining room, wooden beams and comfortable but basic rooms, you can't fault it. Food is filling, with a continental breakfast in the morning and friendly staff to give you any advice. They also offer a laundry service if you need some clean clothes for your hike! Find out more and see other hotels in El Chaltén.

description.web: Hostería Balmaceda is located at the mouth of the Serrano River, where it empties in Last Hope Sound. There are views of Glacier Serrano and Mt Balmaceda from here.

description.web: Hornopiren meaning 'snow-oven', is a wide, cone-shaped mountain and active volcano in the Los Lagos region in Chilean Patagonia. The last eruption was said to have taken place in 1835 although there are no first hand accounts about this occurence. The volcano and its small town are a growing hiking destination due to the spectacular beauty of the snow covered mountain. To find out how you can visit, see our Patagonia Chile page.

description.web: This lovely quaint B&B in Puerto Natales is a great place to stay before your trek in Torres del Paine. With authentic decor, wood stoves lit in each comunal area, comfy beds and a hearty breakfast, this newly renovated hotel offers a great place to stay at reasonable rates. No bedroom is the same which gives the place its character and charm. View this hotel and more on our Hotels in Puerto Natales page.

description.web: Close to the entrance to the Valle Ascencio, the comfortable Hotel Las Torres is in sight of the Paine Massif. The hotel lies on the route of the popular W Trek, and is not far from the Torres del Paine Lookout. Accommodation ranges from small cosy rooms to spacious suites complete with jacuzzi and view of the mountains. The hotel offers all inclusive packages with programs including trekking and horse riding. >> Read more and check availability for Hosteria Las Torres

description.web: Hotel Lago Grey lies on the edge of the lake from which it takes its name, within Torres del Paine National Park. This is a comfortable base from which to visit Glaciar Grey or sail on Lago Grey, both of which can be seen from superior rooms. There are several trekking opportunities nearby and the hotel offers various excursions.

description.web: Literally translated as the "Island of the Dead", the inhabitants of Tortel have left this island steeped in mystery after burying thirty-three people here almost one-hundred years ago. The cause of their deaths remains unknown, but their crosses remain and provide a certain eeriness to an otherwise beautiful scene at the delta of one of Chile's most important rivers, the Baker.

description.web: A set of four islands, located no more than 20 km from Ushuaia. They form a natural harbour offering shelter from the strong winds characteristic of the Beagle Channel. For this region the islands are popular for diving and kayaking. The islands get their name from the local Bridges family, who helped the Argentinian government colonise the area and lived peacfully amongst the native Yaghana people in their Estancia Harberton. The islands have the biggest 'concheros' in the region, which are circular shell deposits created by the Yaghana people after eating lots of seafood. To find out more about the Estancia and the Beagle Channel visit our Ushuaia page.

description.web: Islote Conejos is located in the Queilen Channel on the east coast of Chiloé Island. There is a colony of Magellanic penguins on the island.

description.web: Found in the Aisen region, this island is a natural sanctuary for flora and fauna and is pretty much untouched.

description.web: Isla Martillo, or Maritllo Island, is a small island home to a penguin colony in the Beagle Channel in Tierra del Fuego. This island, along with Gable Island, belongs to the nearby Estancia Harberton, and were bequeathed to the Bridges family that lives there thanks to their extensive work with the Yaghan natives from Tierra del Fuego and as a reward for helping the Argentinian government to colonise this area. On Isla Martillo you can walk amongst the penguins and take some brilliant photos by going on a guided boat tour.

description.web: Jorge Newbery (AEP) airport is the domestic airport in Buenos Aires. International flights come into the oher main airport in Buenos Aires, Ezeiza (EZE), so you'll need to travel between the two if you're flying into Patagonia via Buenos Aires. Here you can find out more about the airports in Buenos Aires.

description.web: Islote Barrientos is located in Chile and is home to one of the largest bird colonies in the country. Kelp gulls, rock shags, red-legged shags and imperial shags as well as South American fur seals can all be seen here.

description.web: This heart shaped island is found in the middle of the Mascardi Lake in Nahuel Huapi National Park in the Bariloche region of Argentinian Patagonia. The lake itself stretches some 14 by 3 miles with many branches forming from the lake. It's here that many kayaking trips start out and follow a route around the heart shaped island. To visit this island and to find out more about all the adventures on offer in this region, see Bariloche.Also find out about Kayaking in the Lake District >>

description.web: Lago Brush or Brush Lake is a pretty lake close to the Rio Serrano in Torres del Paine National Park. The lake is a popular spot for camping out under the stars and is often visited by people on horse back. Having said that, this part of the famous Chilean park is far quieter with fewer people than on the W Circuit and Full Circuit tracks. Find out more about visiting Torres del Paine.

Having said that, this part of the famous Chilean park is far quieter with fewer people than on the W Circuit and Full Circuit tracks. Find out more about visiting Torres del Paine.

description.web: Lago Calafquén is a beautiful glacial lake in the Chilean Lake District, straddling the border between the La Araucanía and Los Ríos regions, and is a popular summer destination known for its beaches and water sports with the Villarrica Volcano as a stunning backdrop.

description.web: The town of Cholila is just a few miles to the east of this lake. This is where Butch Cassidy and the Sundance kid allegedly set themselves up as cattle breeders in the early 20th century before a final bank raid in Rio Gallegos.

description.web: Lago Correntoso is a beautiful lake located in Nahuel Huapi National Park, near the town of Villa La Angostura in Neuquén Province, Argentina, known for its stunning turquoise waters and for being connected to Lake Nahuel Huapi by the famous and very short Correntoso River

description.web: 250 km north of Coyhaique, La Junta lies near the confluence of the Rio Rosselot and Rio Palena. A sizeable settlement of over 1,200 people, you'll be able to find necessities for your roadtrip here, such as a petrol station, a supermarket, a mechanic, and access to the internet. You may have trouble finding an ATM, however.

description.web: Lago Futalaufquen ( futa meaning big ; laufquen meaning lake) is the source of water that ultimately flows into the Rio Futaleufu (yes, you guessed it big river ), one of the world's most renowned whitewater rafting rivers, and one that flows all the way to the Pacific ocean.

description.web: Lago Electrico lies about 10km north of Mount Fitz Roy, as the crow flies. It is filled by the meltwater of the Marconi Glacier on the eastern edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap.On its western edge lies La Playita, campsite with no services other than a few piles of rocks to provide some shelter from the wind, which is normally used en route to the Ice CapTo get there you normally start out from the bridge on the Rio Electrico (around 20 mins drive north of El Chaltén) and hike through woodland along the banks of the river to Piedra del Fraile. The hike from Piedra del Fraile to La Playita is more challenging but has a clearly marked path.From the Electrico lake and river there are a couple of side-hikes worth exploring: the Pollone Valley and Piedra Negra. Both of these are best tackled with a guide.

description.web: Located 62 miles north of the Patagonian town of Ushuaia, this glacial-formed lake is one of the largest in the world and is split between Chile and Argentina. The lake offers over 72 miles of beach to enjoy and is a great place for trekking, fishing and seeing a bit of Tierra del Fuego by boat.

description.web: An Argentinian lake close the border with Chile; Lago Currhuhue Grande and to the east Lago Curruhue Chico.

description.web: This stunning lake is found in Los Glaciares National Park and is usually reached in around 90 minutes via the road north of El Chaltén, a popular climbers town established in 1985. The view from Lago del Desierto is really beautiful and gives another perspective of the park's famous granite peak, Cerro FitzRoy, which was first noted on 2nd March 1877 by Perito Moreno. He named it in hour of Robert FitzRoy who chartered large parts of the Patagonian coast. Lago del Desierto is a particularly good spot for seeing Patagonia's native flora and fauna, including the red-headed Magellanic woodpecker and the pan del indio, a bright orange fungus. Find out more about visiting El Chaltén and Los Glaciares National Park >>

description.web: Lago del Toro is the largest lake in the Torres del Paine National Park and many visitors to the national park drive along its shore as they first catch sight of the famous Towers and the 'Cuernos'. The Rio Serrano flows from the north west corner of the lake. Also in the north west corner of the lake lies the park administration centre; CONAF are based here and you will also find the road leading to Camping Serrano, a lovely campsite at the edge of the Rio Serrano, which is one of the lesser known places in the park and a fantastic spot for relaxing, fishing and kayaking south into the wilderness.

description.web: Lago Falkner (Lago Filo Hua Hum) is located in the Nahuel Napi National Park. Around it's shores are many forest trails and gravel roads, popular for mountain biking.

description.web: Close to the border with Argentina, this tranquil lake in the Chilean Lake District is difficult to reach by car and is usually accessed by motorboat, on foot or on horseback. Isla Barrundias, a small island in the northern part of the lake is privately owned and many horse riding groups stay at the picturesque lodge there. With just a few short boat rides across Lago Rocas, Lago Inferior and the rapids in the middle of Lago Puelo, you will arrive in Argentina within a couple of hours.

description.web: Lago Jeinimeni National Park is a stunning wilderness area in the Aysén Region of Chilean Patagonia, now integrated as a sector within the expansive Patagonia National Park. It is known for its beautiful turquoise lake, dramatic mountain landscapes, and unique attractions, including ancient rock art and the striking "Piedra Clavada" rock formation.

description.web: The biggest lake in Chile, it crosses the Chilean-Argentine border and is share by both countries. (In Argentina, it is known as Lago Buenos Aires). The lake's glacial waters drain into the Pacific via the Rio Baker, Chile's most voluminous river. The area was highly isolated for many years and accessible only from the Argentine side. However, the construction of the Carretera has allowed for tourism to boom here, becoming a very popular destiation for Chileans on their summer holidays. The major attraction is the Marble Cathedral (Marmol de Catedral, a.k.a. the Marble Caves).

description.web: From the beach at the southern end of Lago Grey you get spectacular views of Glacier Grey far away at the northern end, some 17km walking distance away. You can reach Grey beach by taking a private transfer from Puerto Natales or coming at it from within the park, by crossing the lake by boat. The boat sets off from Refugio Grey near the spiky point at the top right of the lake by the glacier, at 1pm. It's lovely to walk along Grey beach and there are some W Trek trips, winter trips and kayaking trips that allow you to make the most of the views of los Cuernos mountains and the Paine Massif from this angle.

description.web: Lago Lácar is a stunning glacial lake in Argentine Patagonia's Lanín National Park, famous for its deep blue waters surrounded by lush forests and mountains. It serves as the picturesque setting and main recreational hub for the popular tourist city of San Martín de los Andes, which sits on its eastern shore.

description.web: Lago Maihue is a beautiful, glacier-fed lake in the Andes mountains of southern Chile, located in the Los Ríos Region. It is known for its serene, pristine waters surrounded by dense native forests and is a popular destination for fishing, kayaking, and relaxation, draining west into the larger Ranco Lake.

description.web: A beautiful turquoise green lake in the northern part of Torres del Paine National Park, Lago Paine is one of the highlights of the Full Circuit and is seen by only 5% of the visitors to the park. The lake is reasonably close to Lago Dickson, another beautiful lake in this part of Patagonia and a popular area for cycling and horse riding. It's also from here that you have fantastic views of the Paine Massif and the back of the Torres, from which the park gets its name. Find out more visiting Torres del Paine.

description.web: The Lago Nahuel Huapi is 6.3 miles wide and gives its name to the nearby national park. One of its branches, named 'Sadness branch' or Brazo Tristeza, is surrounded by towering, snow-capped mountains, lush forests and lakes as far as the eye can see. Nearby is the ever growing town of Bariloche, a sort of alpine-style place, famous for its chocolate making. It is here that many great kayaking itineraries start out and take you down to Tristeza branch via private transfer. If you're coming to this part of the Argentinian Patagonia Lake District, kayaking in the quiet waters of the Nahuel Huapi branch is definitely not to be missed, as well as hiking and mountain biking in the nearby hills and visiting the luxury ski resort of Cerro Catedral.

description.web: This is a huge lake fed by several glaciers in the North of the El Chaltén and Fitz Roy region. The lake spans the border of Chile and Argentina and is known as Lago O'Higgins in Chile but Lago San Martin in Argentina.

description.web: Lago Pehoé sits at the centre of Torres del Paine National Park, and from it you have wonderful views of the Paine Grande mountain and the Cuernos (horns) del Paine. Pehoé is a tehuelche word meaning 'hidden' and is pronounced "pay-oh-way".On its northwestern shore lies Refugio Paine Grande, one of the key paces to spend a night on the W Trek. Watching the sun set on Lago Pehoé from Camping or Refugio Paine Grande is a peaceful and rewarding end to a day of hiking along the Grey Lake or up the French Valley . To the North East is the Salto Grande waterfall, and to the South East the Salto Chico waterfall and a number of accommodation options: Hosteria Pehoé, Camping Pehoé and the Explora Hotel . Most visitors first catch a glimpse of the lake whilst hiking the W Trek. However, the views from its Western shores are wonderful and the 4 to 5 hour hike (or horseride) up from the National Park's administration centre is a relatively flat and less trodden route.The lake is large, more than 10km wide, and the ferry across takes approximately an hour, from Paine Grande Lodge to the North East .

description.web: Perhaps one of the bluest lakes in the Argentinian lake district, Lago Puelo is vast and calm, apart from the fast flowing rapids in the middle of the lake, which can be crossed on a motor boat. After crossing Puelo, you're about a hour's drive from El Bolson, a small hippy town, with a small market selling artesan products and good ice cream parlours. For best views of the snow-capped mountains in the distance, get up early and catch Ken's motor boat across the lake whilst there's still some mist.

description.web: Lying in the heart of Torres del Paine National Park, Lago Nordenskjold is a lake with unique colours, at the south western end of which you will find the magnificent Salto Grande waterfall. Walking along the shore of the lake affords spectacular views of Valle Frances and the Paine Massif.
