description.final: Lying in the heart of Torres del Paine National Park, Lago Nordenskjold is a lake with unique colours, at the south western end of which you will find the magnificent Salto Grande waterfall. Walking along the shore of the lake affords spectacular views of Valle Frances and the Paine Massif.

description.web: Lago Nahuel Huapi is perfect for kayaking as its situated in the bustling tourist town of Bariloche, which has built up around this pristine lake. From Bariloche's many viewpoints you get greats vistas of Lago Nahuel Huapi and its surrounding lakes and mountains. More about the Argentine Lake District >>

description.web: For spectacular views out over the region and for fantastic kayaking opportunities, Lago Perito Moreno (named after the famous scientist and national Argentinian hero, Perito Francisco Moreno), the Lago Moreno is set against a backdrop of forests and lakes as far as the eye can see. For first time kayakers and for those looking for the calm waters of a lake rather than some rough and ready sea kayaking, Lago Perito Moreno offers a wonderful introduction to kayaking in the area. Find out more about this region on our kayaking in Bariloche page.

description.web: Many people come to Bariloche to kayak on and explore its beautiful lakes, and this lake is no exception. A reasonably still and quiet lake, it's a perfect place to kayak and take in spectacular views of surrounding mountains and forests. There is also the option of float fishing here.

description.web: This small lake in the very northern part of Torres del Paine, is one of the highlights of getting off the beaten track. A hike to Lago or Laguna Quemada gives you a unique view of Glacier Dickson, especially if you leave early from Refugio Dickson. From the lake it's also possible to continue along an old baqueano trail to the international police post. This quiet and picturesque part of the park is usually reached whilst trekking the Full Circuit of Torres del Paine.

description.web: Lake Sarmiento is located in Torres del Paine National Park, in Chile. It is named after Spanish explorer Pedro Sarmiento de Gamboa, and gives its name to one of the areas in the National Park Torres del Paine. Its edge is marked by extensive calcium carbonate ‘Thrombolite’ deposits, possibly from hydrothermal activity in the lake.

description.web: A vast and turquoise blue lake in the Chilean Lake District, All Saints Lake is close to Puerto Varas and within the boundaries of the Vicente Pérez Rosales National Park. Although a beautiful place, few people kayak on or trek close to the lake, it's rather used as a means of getting across the many lakes in the Chilean Lake District over to Argentina or vice versa by boat. More information about the Lake District >>

description.web: Fed by the meltwaters of Glaciar Tyndall which comes down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Field, Tyndall Lake can be reached via the Tyndall River, just outside the boundaries of Torres del Paine National Park. A hotspot for kayaking trips, on Lago Tyndall you paddle up the icy walls of the 12000-year old glacier and enjoy lunch on the lake's sandy shores.

description.web: Laguna Azul lies in the North East of Torres del Paine National Park. Its eastern edge can be reached by road/track and there's a campsite. It doesn't sit on either the W or the Full Circuit, but is accessible on guided treks and horseriding trips. It is also a popular location for puma-tracking.

description.web: One of Tierra del Fuego's huge blue lakes, Lago Yehuin is visited on a trekking adventure in the Argentinian part of Tierra del Fuego, close to Ushuaia and the gigantic Lago Fagnano. It's not an easy location to reach so is definitely best visited with a local guide from the area. Find more information about trekking in Tierra del Fuego and visiting the southernmost city in the world, Ushuaia.

description.web: A large lake in the Futaleufu river system, Lago Yelcho boasts an abundance of Brown and Rainbow trout and is a great spot for fly fishing. The lake is in a quiet and secluded area with lovely views of the surrounding mountains. Good accommodation and guides are provided at the Isla Monita Lodge, which is situated on a private island on the lake.

description.web: Laguna Amarga is one of the best places on earth to observe pumas in the wild. Nowhere else the population density is as high as on this Ranch. Previously it was common practice for the land owners to hunt pumas, in order to avoid that those kill their sheep. Now however, there has grown a new generation on the Estancias, advocating for a tolerant cooperation. Now you can watch the pumas in their natural habitat while on the same Estancia there is being practiced livestock farming, whereupon the sheep are being guarded by livestock guardian dogs, so that they don’t fall prey to the pumas. Read our guide to puma tracking in Torres del Paine

description.web: Laguna Cejar is a stunning, highly saline lagoon located in the Atacama Salt Flat near San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, famous for its incredible buoyancy that allows visitors to float effortlessly on its turquoise waters, similar to the Dead Sea.
description.quote: Laguna Cejar is a stunning, highly saline lagoon located in the Atacama Salt Flat near San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, famous for its incredible buoyancy that allows visitors to float effortlessly on its turquoise waters, similar to the Dead Sea.

description.web: Laguna de los Tres is probably the most famous and most popular viewpoint for Cerro Fitz Roy. "Los Tres" refers to the three peaks that you can see from the laguna's shore: Fitz Roy (3,405m), Poincenot (3,002m), and Saint-Exupéry (2,558m), but the view is magnificient around all 360 degrees.This is a very popular destination, for good reason, so don't expect any solitude if you're there between November and February. The path up is well trodden and relatively easy going, with some steeper sections towards the top. Whilst there's only one approach to the laguna and the viewpoint, you can incorporate it into your itinerary in a few different ways: - Day hike from El Chaltén. This is a route where you have to retrace your steps, but it's a varied and interesting route and the round-trip might take around 8 to 9 hours. - Start from Hosteria Pilar or Piedra del Fraile campsite to the North, and return back to El Chaltén at the end of the day. This is again a full day of around 8 to 9 hours, but has the benefit of taking in Glaciar Piedras Blancas in the first part of the day, and you don't need to retrace your steps. - Use Camping Poincenot as base. This is a good option if you want to break it into shorter days; from here it's about an hour up to the viewpoint. The campsite is nice, if a little busy, and around a 3 hour hike from El Chaltén.

description.web: Laguna Los Perros in the northern part of Torres del Paine National Park is a small lake with the large Glacier Perros flowing into it. It's one of the many highlights of the Full Circuit trek, which takes 8-10 days to complete, along with Paso John Garner, which looks out over the sprawling Glacier Grey. Perros offers a campsite for hikers and did used to have a refugio, but sadly this burnt down a couple of years ago. To find out more, read our guide to Torres del Paine.

description.web: Laguna Piedras Blancas is filled by the meltwater of the beautiful and dramatic glacier of the same name, which descending from the East of Mount Fitz Roy. You can hike to Piedras Blancas from the north along the valley of the Rio Blanco. On its eastern edge (from Hosteria El Pilar), or its western edge (from Piedra del Fraile campsite). In the case of the latter you can actually reach the shore of the laguna.

In the case of the latter you can actually reach the shore of the laguna.

description.web: Laguna Salto is located on Isla Navarino in Chilean Patagonia. Trekkers often camp on the shore of the lagoon.

description.web: Named after the gloriously blue San Rafael Lagoon, formed by the meltwater of San Rafael Glacier. In 1979 the Park was designated a UNESCO World Biosphere Reserve and some of the highest peaks of the Patagonian Andes (Mt Valentin). Its protected status means that it is home to many kinds of wildlife, including Chilean dolphins, sea lions, marine otters, and elephant seals.

description.web: This is a group of three lakes, which lies on a trekking route not far from the town of El Chaltén, in the shadow of Mount Fitz Roy. Laguna Madre is the largest and its name literally means 'mother'. The next largest is Hija, meaning 'daughter', and the smallest by far is Nieta, meaning 'granddaughter'.

description.web: Lake Tagua Tagua is a glacial finger lake in the Chilean Lake District sitting in 3000 hectares of forest that was turned into a Private Protected Area in 2013 dedicated to ecotourism. Access is by boat from the jetty at Puerto Canelo on Tagua Tagua’s northernmost point, a short walk from a cascading waterfall that marks the point where the Puelo River flows out of the lake to begin its descent to the Reconlavi Fjord. It’s possible to kayak near the falls or paddle to one of the lake’s many stony beaches. The surrounding landscape is thick with temperate rainforest and braided with well-marked hiking trails and walkways that climb the park’s steep slopes. The forest is well planted with Chilean cypress trees as well as ancient alerces, some of which might be as old as 3000 years. Under their branches, the forest floor is thick with ferns and fuschias that thrive in the damp alpine climate. The park has three refugios, Notros, Alerces and Quetrus. The first is near the entrance to the park, while the other two reward hikers prepared for a 7km and 10km respectively with truly spectacular locations. Refugio Alerces looks out across the ghostly fingers of long-dead alerces trees poking out from the waters, while Refugio Quetrus is at is near a smaller lake of the same name, which opens out to give tremendous views of the surrounding granite peaks. At the southern end of Lake Tagua Tagua is the Mitico Puelo Lodge , a former fishing lodge offering hikers a taste of mountain luxury. Lake Tagua Tagua is around a four hour drive from either Puerto Montt or Puerto Varas, via Cochamó. Mitico Puelo Lodge is a 40-minute boat ride from the Puerto Canelo jetty.

description.web: Two hours drive from both Bariloche and San Martín de los Andes, Lake Filo Hua Hum is a popular camping destination for cyclists. The quiet gravel roads in this area are perfect for mountain biking, allowing cyclists to pedal from between a number of secluded lakes here. The Filo Hua Hum river runs through the lake on its way to nearby Lake Falkner. It is well-stocked with both brown and rainbow trout, making it a top fly fishing destination. The fish rise at their most enthusiastic in the lake from December to February, allowing food fishing from drift boats.There is a tranquil campsite on the southern shore of the lake. A gravel road north from Filo Hua Hum leads to Lake Meliquina , and on to San Martín de los Andes.

description.web: Lapostolle Winery is a renowned Chilean winery, founded by Alexandra Marnier Lapostolle (of the Grand Marnier family), located primarily in the Colchagua Valley, specifically near the town of Santa Cruz and particularly in the famous Apalta Valley. It is celebrated for combining French winemaking expertise with Chile's exceptional terroir to produce world-class wines, most notably their iconic "Clos Apalta."

description.web: Found in the heart of the Tierra del Fuego National Park, Lapataia Bay offers a secluded spot to kayak and see many native varieties of Patagonian birds including the Patagonian goose. This is one of the highlights of kayaking in Tierra del Fuego as you are able to paddle alongside colonies of cormorants and even past seals. If you're lucky you'll spot a couple of minxes that live in this area too. Find out more about visiting Tierra del Fuego either by kayak or by foot.

description.web: The 'Cuernos' of Torres del Paine are some of the most impressive peaks in this beautiful national park. Along with the Towers of Paine, The Cuernos are one of the main highlights visited on the W Circuit hike which takes 4-5 days to complete. The Cuernos form a cirque of impressive cliffs at the top of the French Valley. The walls of Cerro Cota 2000 rise sharply to the west. This mountain gets its name from the fact that its highest contour line is about 2,000 m (6,562 ft). Cerro Catedral is named so because its east face resembles a cathedral's facade. To the north stands the granite spire called Aleta de Tiburón or Shark's Fin, to the east, lie La Fortaleza (Fortress), La Espada (The Sword), La Hoja (The Blade), La Máscara (The Mummer), Cuerno Norte (North Horn), and Cuerno Principal (Main Horn). Some of the best photos of Los Cuernos are taken on board the boat across Lake Pehoé, directly beneath Los Cuernos. Find out more about visiting these impressive mountains and trekking in Torres del Paine.

description.web: Llancahué hot springs are the perfect place to chill out after a hard days kayaking on Llancahué Island close to Parque Nacional Hornopiren in Chilean Patagonia. These hot springs are really warm and can reach up to 52°C, making them great to relax. It takes about 50 minutes to get to the island by motorboat from Hornopirén via the Cholgo Channel and it's a great way to see this beautiful area of Patagonia which has lots of quaint fishing villages, hot springs, seals and whales.

Even if you're a beginner the river is a great place to raft as its different sections are perfect for different levels of ability.

description.web: The Marconi Pass is one of only three passes onto the South Patagonian Ice Field . Coming from La Playita campsite at Lago Electrico, you climb 1,000 metres (3,250 feet) up the Marconi Glacier to reach the pass at an altitude of 1,517m above sea level.

description.web: The Manso River lies in the heart of the Patagonian Lake District on the Argentinian side and is a perfect place for whitewater rafting in Patagonia. This part of the world is lush, green and surrounded by lakes and valdivian jungle. The river itself is a top spot for fishing and even more so, white water rafting. The river starts from Manso Glacier and its waters fill the lakes of Mascardi, Los Moscos, Hess and Steffen. It's split into sections thanks to these lakes which divide it, and each section has a different level of rafting difficulty. The lower section, Manso Inferior, is a class III river which has fast flowing rapids perfect for thrill seekers. Parts of the river there are quite still and a good place to enjoy some swimming too. The lower section Manso Inferior to the Frontier (Chilean border) is a class III/IV river, which makes it even more exciting for adrenaline lovers as it enters a canyon and drops quicker as it flows to the Pacific.

description.web: This is a highly tidal waterway separating Tierra del Fuego from the mainland. It's possible to cross the straits by ferry, from Punta Arenas to Tierra del Fuego. It's then a 12 hour bus journey down to Ushuaia. Adventure cruises on the Magellan Straits and Beagle Channel afford visitors to this region the chance to get up close to glaciers, waterfalls, penguin colonies and more. The southern tip of Patagonia is home to some incredible spectacles, many of which can only be accessed from the water. Several cruises here also allow you to see Cape Horn. More Information about Cruises in Tierra del Fuego >>

description.web: Located in the Magellan Straits, this island is home to a huge colony of Magellanic penguins who come here to breed, nest and feed throughout the year. A popular spot on many Austral adventure cruises, this island allows you to get up close to the penguins before arriving in Ushuaia, the southernmost city in the world. In the past the island was an essential source of supplies for navigators and explorers, hence the seaside red and white striped lighthouse which still guides today's ships through the Magellan Straits. Find out more about how to see Penguins on this island!

description.web: Mendoza is a large city in western Argentina, internationally recognized as the heart of Argentina's wine industry, with hundreds of wineries, and also serves as a major base for mountaineering and outdoor adventures in the nearby Andes Mountains, including climbing the highest peak in the Americas, Aconcagua.

description.web: A very short walk from El Chaltén takes you to this viewpoint, from which you will have spectacular views of Cerro Fitz Roy, Cerro Torre and the valley of Rio de las Vueltas. As the name suggests, this is a good location to spot condors, which regularly fly between the Fitz Roy and Vueltas valleys. This is a great place to get panoramic shots of the dramatic landscape, particularly at sunrise.

description.web: To the west of the park and off all of the main trails, this mirador ('look-out point') offers a unique perspective on the national park and you're unlikely to see more than a handful of people on the trail. It's a fairly steep 2 hour climb, from the parking area next to Hotel Grey, up a well marked path to the top. Up top you are pretty free to rome and find a sheltered spot to admire the Paine Massif, the Grey Glacier and most of the lakes of Torres del Paine National Park's lakes, each a different shade of blue.

description.web: This famous viewpoint is located a short walk above Laguna Torre, which can be reached on a day-trek from the town of El Chaltén. The viewpoint is named after Cesare Maestri, who claimed to be the first to climb Cerro Torre, although it is thought to be very unlikely that he actually did. As well as views of the dominating peak of Cerro Torre, with Torre Egger and Cerro Standhardt beside it, this viewpoint also gives you spectacular views of Glaciars Grande and Torre, originating high in the mountains and coming down to the laguna below.

description.web: The Mylodon Cave is located in Chilean Patagonia, 24km (15 miles) northwest of Puerto Natales and 270km (168 miles) north of Punta Arenas. The cave is located on the side of Cerro Benitez and comprises several caves and a rock formations called Silla del Diablo (Devil's Chair). The cave is notable for the discovery in 1895 of the remains of a giant ground sloth called Mylodon darwinii.

description.web: From this viewpoint on the slopes of Loma del Pliegue Tumbado there are stunning views on all sides. As well as a unique perspective on the massifs of Torre and Fitz Roy, there are extensive views over the valleys below them and, in other directions, the Patagonian Steppe and the vast Lago Viedma. The viewpoint can be reached on a day-trek from El Chaltén, which takes you up through forest to an area just above 1000 metres, where it is possible to find remains of marine fossils.

description.web: In December 2004, Montes inaugurated the new winery at Apalta. The investment totaled over U$ 7 million with a storing capacity of 2,300,000 litres. A cellar that becomes a qualitative production leap for one of the most applauded Montes red wines: Montes Alpha and the Ultra-Premium Montes Alpha M and Montes Folly in addition to the recently launched Purple Angel.

description.web: Stopping off at the Mitico Puelo Lodge makes crossing the Andes between Chile and Argentina a particularly special experience. The lodge is small and secluded - it is inaccessible by road - and the staff provide excellent service. Led by friendly and experienced guides, the excursions on offer help you make the most of the beautiful landscape of the Lake District, whether by foot, bike, horse or kayak. >>> Find out more about Mitico Puelo Lodge

description.web: The Mocho-Choshuenco volcanic complex comprises two prominent stratovolcanoes, Mocho (2,422 m) and Choshuenco (2,415 m), located in the Los Ríos Region of the Chilean Andes. They are an active, ice-clad volcanic system known for their scenic beauty within the Mocho-Choshuenco National Reserve, offering opportunities for hiking, climbing, and winter sports.

description.web: This city is the Capital of the Province of Neuquen in Argentina found in the north of Patagonia, and it is situated at the origin of the River Negro. With a population of 265,000 it is the largest city in Patagonia. It's nearby airport serves most of patagonia including San Carlos de Bariloche, Buenos Aires and Ushuaia.

description.web: Mt Carabajal is located around 10 miles/15km west of Ushuaia, off the Ruta 3 highway. Hiking to the summit of this mountain, and visiting Laguna Turquesa en route, is one of the best day hikes you can do from Ushuaia.

description.web: Located in the Chliean part of Tierra del Fuego, Mount Darwin forms part of the Cordillera of the Andes Mountain Range and is famous for being the highest peak in the region, towering in this wild and vast land at 2,488 metres (8,163 ft). Mount Darwin was given its name by the captain of HMS Beagle, Robert FitzRoy in order to commemorate Darwin's 25th birthday on 12th February 1834. Mount Darwin is a challenging peak to climb and is best attempted well into Patagonian summer, from December to March.

Mount Darwin is a challenging peak to climb and is best attempted well into Patagonian summer, from December to March.

description.web: Fed by the North Patagonian Ice Cap the Neff Glacier is one of the more accessible in the region. It is the fifth largest of the Northern Ice Field's glaciers How to see it: Road Trips Although realtively accessible, Neff's location in Aisen means that it isn't amid the main travel hotspots of Torres del Paine and Los Glaciares. That is no bad thing, hoewever: take a roadtrip along the Carreera Austral - Chile's famous highway that runs the spine of Chile - and enjoy the Glacier all to yourself. Ski-Touring For those with some experience, take on the glaciers of the Norh Patagonian Ice Field with your trusted pair of skiis. Ice-Hiking Alternatively, don your crampons and ice-axe and take to Neff Glacier, crossing it as part of a broader tour of Aysen's glaciers. More Details >>

description.web: Cerro Tronador , standing at 3,491m, is the highest mountain in the Lake District region around San Carlos de Bariloche. Tronador means 'thunderer' and that really is the sound you hear on approach, as ice calves off the glaciers into a natural amphitheatre below. With a day hike from Bariloche you can get up close to its glaciers. It's also possible to climb Tronador; this is a 3 day expedition, summitting on Day 2, and using the Meiling mountain hut on the first and second nights. There are actually a few different peaks on Tronador and for introductory/intermediate trips you'd tackle the 'Pico Argentino' at 3,187m. Tronador lies in the heart of Nahuel Huapi National Park, and is accessed via Pampa Linda, a short drive from San Carlos de Bariloche. It is also the source of the Manso River, one of the top white water rafting rivers in the region.

description.web: Cerro Castillo is Spanish for "Castle Peak", and you can certainly see why - the jagged outcrops of rock make it look like the fort you always dreamed of playing in as a child! It is 2 675m high and can be climbed along two main routes.

description.web: A spa hotel in Puerto Natales based on the Last Hope Sound. Spacious modern rooms, with filling breakfast and the icing on the cake; sauna, massage rooms, jacuzzis and loungers. Find out more and other hotels in Puerto Natales.

description.web: Situated in the Chilean Lake District, Alerce Andino is home to more than 50 stunning lakes. With 20,000 hectares of Alerce Forests, there is plenty of nature and scenery to discover. A lovely spot for some day hiking in the Lake District. More about the Lake District >>

description.web: Panguipulli is a town in the heart of the Chilean Lake District, on the northwestern tip of Lake Panguipulli . It sits at the centre of the Seven Lakes Circuit , a notably pretty road route that runs past Lakes Calafqué, Pellaifa, Neltume, Pirehueico, Riñihue, Pullinque, and Panguipulli lakes. The modern town was only founded in the 1940s, but the region itself has been occupied for far longer: Panguipulli means ' Puma hill ' in the Mapudungun language of the original Mapuche inhabitants. Tourists visit Panguipulli for its proximity to the Huilo-Huilo Biological Reserve , as well as the word-class whitewater rafting on the nearby Fuy River , whose rapids are interspersed with a series of dramatic waterfalls. The town also has a noted gastronomic scene, and is famous for its honey, cheese and cider. Panguipulli is 145km (two hours) south of Temuco and its airport, 75km (90 minutes) from Pucón and 235km (three hours) north of Puerto Varas. The latter road in particular is very scenic. The town also offers international connections to Argentina . From nearby Puerto Fuy, a ferry runs along to Lake Pirihueico to the international border at Filo Hua Hum pass, from where a road takes you alongside Lake Lacar to San Martín de los Andes.

description.web: In the Chilean Lake District, Parque Pumalin's temperate rainforests are home to a wide variety of flora and fauna. Its main attraction, however, is its spectacular fjords, and the park is a great destination for kayaking.

description.web: The Oggioni Pass offers a semi-technical route out of the Ascencio Valley and into the Dickson valley area in the north of Torres del Paine national park. It's a tough trek, very much off-the-beaten-track, and only for those up for a challenge. From one of our treks through this pass: The trek leads us 'off trail', up and over steep slopes, showing us views of Torres del Paine National Park that few people see. We push forward through thick forest, crossing wild creeks, and up rocky steep slopes. You should be in very good physical condition for this pass: able to hike long distances, uphill and downhill, with keen mental strength and sense of determination to resist tough elements like strong winds and frozen rain or snowfall (even in the summer). Most of the crossing is along moraine and snow (depending on how much snow this area has received in the last winter). For more info see: trekking the Oggioni Pass and other Torres del Paine treks off-the-beaten-track.

description.web: This Pass crosses the 'Fiver Brothers' Mountain Range in Tierra del Fuego. Hiking through the pass is certainly a challenge due to strong winds and the snow which usually covers the pass and its surrounding mountains. For this reason, it's definitely better to trek this route with a guide. The challenge is all worth it though for the views of the impressive mountains all around you. If you're up for a challenge, find out more about Trekking Tierra del Fuego or it's southernmost city, Ushuaia.

description.web: This airport lies in the extreme North of Patagonia, deep in the Patagonian Steppe. It became a more popular chouice when Bariloche airport was closed in 2011 due to a volcanic ash cloud. There are several flights each day from Buenos Aeres.

description.web: Paso del Viento, or the 'windy pass', is found on the edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap, at 1,428m above sea level . The pass is a 2 day hike from the town of El Chaltén. Read about a customer's trek to Paso del Viento on our blog.

description.web: Paso Beban is a high Mountain Pass in the Sierra Valdivieso mountain chain of Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. It is a challenging and remote location, popular with experienced hikers and mountaineers, and is known for its beautiful, untouched Patagonian landscapes. It is a key point on multi-day trekking routes in the area and is not a place with a conventional address.

description.web: Paso Huemul is a Mountain Pass at 1,005 metres, which lies on the Huemul Circuit in Los Glaciares National Park. From here there are spectacular views of Glaciar Viedma falling into the lake of the same name. Close by, Paso Huemul Campsite can be used by those trekking this circuit, which takes a few days to complete.

description.web: This is a Mountain Pass at 1354 metres on Loma del Pliegue Tumbado. Climbing up to the pass gives you stunning panoramic views of Cerro Torre and Fitz Roy. It is highly recommended that you are accompanied by a guide for this trek. Find out more about Trekking in Los Glaciares >>

description.web: Where to find it Torres del Paine National Park, Chile What is it? Paso John Garner (the John Garner Pass) is one of the most famous passes on the Full Circuit Trek. It is an awe-inspiring pass, with views out across the Grey Glacier and, on a clear day, out across the South Patagonian Ice Cap itself. It's also one of the highest points you are likely to trek to in Torres del Paine, at an altitude of around 1,200 metres above sea level. How can I see it? On the Full Circuit multi-day hike you approach the pass from Laguna Los Perros, from the east. It's very windy up there, and the descent down to the Grey Glacier is one of the toughest sections of the whole trek. However, the views are incredible, and if you've got the time and stamina to do the Full Circuit then this view alone makes it worthwhile. Find out more about... The Full Circuit hike Hiking in Torres del Paine Torres del Paine National Park

description.web: Crossing Paso Guillaumet brings you amazingly close to the eastern face of Mount Fitz Roy and also gives you a great view back down the length of Glaciar Piedras Blancas to Rio Blanco. The trek includes crossing Piedras Blancas glacier and some low difficulty rock climbing. It is a physically demanding trek which requires the use of some technical equipment.

description.web: Paso de la Oveja (Sheep Pass) is a challenging Mountain Pass located in the remote wilderness of the Fuegian Andes in Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. It is often encountered as part of multi-day trekking routes, offering adventurers stunning, rugged Patagonian landscapes. Mountain Pass at 831m above Ushuaia.

description.web: The Paso del Cuadrado is located in the Los Glaciares region. Trek up to this pass through the Eléctrico Valley. The views from the pass are spectacular and include the major peaks of Cerro Torre, Polone and Fitz Roy.

description.web: As one of the most visited parts of Bernardo O'Higgins National Park, the Peel Fjord is a serene and pristine place to visit, with lots of wildlife, nature and a whole host of sparkling glaciers. The best way of getting here is by boat or kayak. To find out more about trips that visit this fjord in the wilderness, see kayaking in Torres del Paine.

description.web: Peninsula Quetrihué is a peninsula in Nahuel Huapi National Park, Argentina, that is home to the world-famous Arrayanes Forest, a unique forest of cinnamon-colored myrtle trees that is a major tourist attraction, reachable by boat from Bariloche or by a 12km trail from Villa La Angostura.

description.web: Located just outside Torres del Paine National Park on the shore of Lago Toro, Patagonia Camp is a collection of luxury 'yurts'. These tented domes are all equipped with hot running water, heating, their own bathroom and a private terrace with views over the lake towards the Paine massif. >>Find out more and check availability for Patagonia Camp

description.web: The marine park in Chubut region is one of the newest of its kind in Argentina and was set up to protect the many different types of wildlife that breed in this area including the Southern Right Whale.

description.final: The marine park in Chubut region is one of the newest of its kind in Argentina and was set up to protect the many different types of wildlife that breed in this area including the Southern Right Whale.

description.web: Set to become part of the Patagonia National Park, Parque Patagonia (or Patagonia Park) is 200,000 acres of grasslands protecting rare and endangered species. The park welcomes visitors to enjoy the undisturbed scenery, hike the trails and explore the land. Find out more >>

description.web: An Argentine ski resort 3-4 hours from Mendoza and close to the Chilean border. It takes its name from Cerro Penitentes which sits behind. In the winter it's a popular spot for local skiiers but come November it becomes the launch pad for mountaineering expeditions up Aconcagua. The fresh nervous faces of climbers coming in wondering if they'll make it, and the inevitably sunburned and haggard faces of those who have come down from their adventure and looking forward to that first cold beer. There are a number of hotels in the little village (and not much else) - we know and recommend Ayelen. From here it's a 10-15 minute drive to the entrance to the Aconcagua Provincial Park, and then a 4 hour hike up to Confluencia Camp a staging post en route to basecamp at Plaza de Mulas.

description.web: This idyllic UNESCO World Heritage site is a mecca for wildlife enthusiasts from around the globe, due to it's abundance of nature's largest and most diverse marine wildlife . The Valdes Peninsula itself is a unique formation stretching some 1,400 square miles along the Atlantic coast of Argentina. A global conservation site for some of the largest marine mammals , who take advantage of it's two unique sheltered inlets .The Valdes Peninsula is home to some of the ocean's largest mammals, including the Southern Right Whale, the Orca, and the Southern Elephant Seal. It is also home to an array of other marine life including dolphins and sea lions, as well as some interesting land dwellers such as guanacos, foxes, hares and armadillos, and a vast selection of bird species.We recommend that you explore Valdes' coves and beaches by sea kayaking over 1-3 days, cycling its sand dunes and heading out in a small boat to get within a few metres of a giant whale and its calf. From there take a couple of days to drive around the Peninsula and walk amongst a Magellanic penguin colony and see a beach full of basking Elephant seals. Peninsula Valdes >>

description.web: Planted in the 90’s and according to the natural conditions of the Maipo Alto for excellence red wines production, Pérez Cruz chose the best varieties for its terroir. The 140 hectares of vines are planted with Cabernet Sauvignon (70%), Carmenere (10%), Merlot (5%), Syrah (5%), Cot or Malbec (5%) and Petit Verdot (5%).

description.web: Plaza de Mulas acts as basecamp for most ascents of Aconcagua, especially the normal route. It's a very well established camp with a range of services including wifi, hot showers and even cold beers. At the peak of the climbing season it can support as many as 200 people. Conditions can vary dramatically with some climbing parties finding it hot and dusty, whereas others arrive to six inches of snow. The camp is filled with people either arriving from Confluencia, setting out on an acclimatisation climb to Cerro Bonnete, or resting before heading to Camp Canada en route to their summit attempt. On most expeditions you'll spend a total of around 5-6 days here, so it starts to feel pretty familiar.

description.web: Argentina's Piedra Parada is a free standing rock in Chubut. The name has gained particular recognition in the climbing world, largely due to the many climbing routes located in the nearby canyon, although there is also some climbing on The Piedra. The closest small town is Gualjaina and major town is Esquel

description.web: This is a really charming campsite in the Electrico valley to the north of Mount Fitz Roy. The "piedra" refers to a huge boulder once dumped in the valley by the glacier. The boulder provides a good degree of shelter in what is otherwise a very exposed valley on the edge of the South Patagonian Ice Cap.The campsite itself is small (maybe 10-15 pitches) and relatively basic (a few shelters for cooking and basic washrooms), but there's a great hut with a wood-burning stove (and a very content dog), and it serves surprisingly good pizzas and cold beers.Piedra del Fraile could either be a destination in itself or a nice stopping off point en route to the Marconi Pass and the Ice Cap , the Polllone valley or Piedra Negra. It takes about 2-3 hours to get here from the Rio Electrico bridge (a 30 min transfer from El Chaltén).

description.web: This remote and pristine islet in the fjords of Chilean Patagonia's coast are visited en route to Puerto Montt on the cruise itinerary from Puerto Natales. A beautiful place to stop and look out at turquoise waters, mountains and trees as far as the eye can see.

description.web: Where to find it Tierra del Fuego, along the Chilean Patagonia coast between Ushuaia and Punta Arenas. The mountains are in the Darwin Range. What is it? Pia Glacier is breathtakingly big. It tumbles down from the mountains into the sea in a secluded corner of the Chilean Fjords, and is one of the highlights of 'Glacier Alley'. Sit on the shore long enough and you're bound to hear it creaking and groaning as the ice moves. If you're lucky, you'll even catch the huge splash as the ice calves from the frozen wall, and crashes into the water. How can I see it? You can visit this glacier on board an adventure cruise from Punta Arenas to Ushuaia, which explores the fjords and channels of Tierra del Fuego, including the Strait of Magellan and Cape Horn. On arriving at the glacier, you'll have the opportunity to head out in a zodiac boat to get the full impact of the glacier's enormity, before disembarking for a hike to a panoramic viewpoint. Our top trips that visit Pia Glacier Find out more about... Adventure cruises in Tierra del Fuego Tierra del Fuego Glaciers in Patagonia

description.web: Perito Moreno is arguably the most famous glacier in Patagonia, and for good reason. Winding for 20 miles down from the Southern Patagonian Ice Cap, it is a truly enormous glacier. Moreover, it is one of only a handful of advancing glaciers in the world, growing by approximately 2 metres per day. Where is it? Perito Moreno glacier lies in Los Glaciares National Park ("Glaciers National Park") in Argentinian Patagonia 80km from El Calafate, which has one of Patagonia's largest airports How to see it: You can visit visit Perito Moreno in all sorts of ways, whether from the comfort of its viewing platforms or on a more adventurous ice-hike on the glacier itself A popular destination for travellers, it is served by the hotels of El Chaltén and the airport in El Calafate Incorporate it into a broader exploration of Los Glaciares and Patagonia

description.web: Campsite for the highly technical and challenging southern face of Cerro Aconcagua. Also acts as a great acclimatisation day from Confluencia Camp for those attempting the Normal Route of Aconcagua. The hike from Confluencia takes you along the Horcones Glacier (Ventisquero Horcones Inferior) and allows you to climb a height comparable with basecamp at Plaza de Mulas.

description.web: The scenic port of Petrohue sits at the westernmost tip of Lake Todos los Santos in the Chilean Lake District, where the turquoise waters drain into the mouth of the Petrohue river. The tiny town is dwarfed by the the mighty snowcapped peak of the Osorno volcano which stands as its backdrop. The port is stop on the Cruce Andino road-and-ferry route from Puerto Varas to Bariloche in Argentina, as well as being home to the Petrohue Lodge hotel.Following the road southwest from the town along the river takes you to the beautiful Saltos de Petrohue , a waterfall where turquoise waters charge dramatically through old lava channels. It is possible to arrange kayaking trips downstream of the falls. The fast-flowing river is also well-stocked with trout, making it an ideal flyfishing location. The Petrohue Lodge on the shore of the lake is the perfect place to base yourself and arrange either of these activities, along with canyoning, rafting and hiking. Petrohue is just under an hours' drive from Puerto Varas. From here, the ferry to Peulla departs daily in the middle of the morning. The trip takes around two hours, with the boat returning in the afternoon.

description.web: The lakeside town of Pucon sits beside the Villarica Volcano in the Chilean Lake District. From here you can summit the volcano to see its smoking crater and magnificent views along a chain of snow-capped volcanoes, and in the nearby Huerquehue National Park, trails lead through ancient forests of monkey-puzzle trees, mirror lakes and waterfalls. If you fancy rafting or kayaking, then staying in one of Pucon’s wooden lodges gives you plenty of opportunity for this too. More about Pucon >>

description.web: Puerto Almanza is a small village in Tierra del Fuego on the northern shore of the Beagle Channel. It lies about 3km west from another settlement on the channel called Almirante Brown and its almost opposite to the Chilean port of Puerto Williams.It's mostly a resting point for fishermen and is an access point to some local ranches in Tierra del Fuego when roads are cut due to bad weather.

It lies about 3km west from another settlement on the channel called Almirante Brown and its almost opposite to the Chilean port of Puerto Williams.It's mostly a resting point for fishermen and is an access point to some local ranches in Tierra del Fuego when roads are cut due to bad weather.

description.web: Located at the gateway to Torres del Paine, one could assume that Puerto Natales airport would be one of the busiest airports in the area. However, with its sporadic flights, out-of-town location, and complete shut down over winter, Puerto Natales airport receives only a fraction of Torres del Paine's visitors every year. With many more options available, this small airport invariably loses out to reliable public buses and the larger, more comfortable Punta Arenas airport.

description.web: Puerto Natales sits on the edge of the Last Hope Sound (Ultima Eperanza Fjord) and is the gateway to Torres del Paine, in Chilean Patagonia. It lies 247km north of Punta Arenas (Chilean Patagonia's main airport), and 147km from Torres del Paine National Park. Founded in 1911 it was once a key port for the sheep and wool industry, but its main industry is now tourism and it is well set up to support people heading into Torres del Paine National Park. There are a range of accommodation options available, from backpacker hostels to luxury lodges and spas. Find Hotels in Puerto Natales >>In terms of preparations for trekking in Torres del Paine you'll find everything you need here. Shops sell camping equipment, including gas cannisters, and other gear. There is even a North Face shop. However, prices are often higher than in the UK.If you have a spare day then the Cueva de Milodon and the Visitor Centre are worth a visit.

description.web: Puerto Ibanez lies on the northern shores of Lago General Carrera close to where the Rio Ibanez joins it. It serves as a border crossing point into Argentina as well as a port for ferries across the Lake to Chile Chico on the southern shore.

description.web: Puerto Montt is the capital of Chile’s Los Lagos region, and serves as one of the major entry points to the Chilean Lake District and Chiloé island, as well as cruises through the Llanquihue Archipelago to the epic landscapes of Chile's northern fjords. It’s set in a spectacular location on the Reloncaví Sound, fringed with richly forested mountains, but the city itself is very much a working port: most travellers quickly transit the city to make the short hop to the pretty adventure hub of Puerto Varas, a quick 30 minute drive away, or to Vicente Pérez Rosales National Park to climb Osorno volcano.The city’s no-frills atmosphere is underlined by the fact that it was levelled by an earthquake in 1960, almost completely destroying the alpine architecture beloved by the German colonists who founded the town in 1853. The Catedral de Puerto Montt , built in alerce wood with a copper dome three years after the town was established, is the city’s oldest building. The city is built on Mapuche territory, but human habitation here stretches back farther than almost anywhere in the whole of the Americas. At nearby Monte Verde , archaeological remains including hearths, butchered animal remains and even a human footprint were uncovered in 1975 dating back around 18,500 years – a discovery that pushed back the earliest arrival of people on the South American continent by 1000 years. Puerto Montt’s Tepual airport (code PMC) is just 16km west of the town and is served by both LAN and Sky Airlines. From here you can fly to Santiago in just two hours, or south to Punta Arenas to access Torres del Paine National Park. If you want to take the scenic route to Torres del Paine, Puerto Montt is also the departure port for the four day/three night Navimag ferry to Puerto Natales, sailing through Chile’s spectacular fjords. There are no direct ferries from here to Chiloé island. Instead, you must drive 62km south on the mainland to Pargua to catch the car ferry to Chacao. Allow around three hours to transit from Puerto Montt to Ancud on Chiloé, including the 30 minute ferry ride. If you’re driving, the coastal road south from the port is considered to be the starting point for Chile’s famous Carretera Austral.

description.web: A pretty town on the eastern coast of Argentina, part of Peninsula Valdes. The wildlife here is truly abundant, if you kayak or take a boat ride out to see, you'll come across killer whales, sea lion colonies and back on land you can walk through a penguin reserve. The nearest airport is that of the Welsh town, Trelew, with regular flights to and from Buenos Aires.

description.web: A small tourist town, Chileans flock to Puerto Tranquilo for their summer holidays, but it is barely open outside of these peak months. The popularity of the town results from its Marble Caves, also known as the Marble Cathedral (capillas de marmol or catedral de marmol, in Spanish). Located on the shores of Lago General Carrera, into which the Rio Tranquilo feeds, the town is close enough to the Caves for you to visit by boat, or even by kayak.

description.web: Puerto Varas sits on the shores of Lago Llanquihue, the largest lake in the Chilean Lake District. The conical 2,650 metre high Osorno Volcano rises from the lake on the opposite shore. The inhabitants of this area of Chile are an interesting fusion of the indigenous Mapuche people, German settlers from the 1850's and people of colonial Spanish decent, which makes the food, architecture and history very different from Southern Patagonia. While staying here, you can visit the nearby emerald waterfalls, hike to the summit of the Osorno Volcano (a day hike), visit the enchanting Chiloe island or kayak on the Petrohue river. More about Puerto Varas >>

description.web: Puñihuil Penguin Colony in Chiloé is the only place in the world where Humboldt and Magellanic penguins nest side by side. The colony is found on three islets around around 27 kilometres southwest of the Gulf of Ancud. Tours to the colony are by small boat: It is not permitted to land on the colony, which was declared a national monument (Monumento Natural Islotes de Puñihuil) in 1999. The penguins live at sea for half the year, but arrive on the islets in October to breed. Chicks tend to hatch around January , in time for the colony to return to sea near the end of March . Puñihuil is only one of several locations to see penguins around Patagonia. Embarking on an adventure cruise around the Magellan Straits and Tierra del Fuego is another popular way to see penguins, or you can take a trip to Peninsula Valdes on the east coast of Argentina, where penguin spotting can be combined with whale-watching.

description.web: A small village of about 300 inhabitants, Puerto Raul Marin Balmaceda sits on an island in the delta of the Rio Palena. A wonderful location, it lies amid the sands and mountains where Chile meets the Pacific Ocean.

description.web: Along the northern half of the Carretera Austral, Pumalin National Park lies between Hornopiren and Chaiten. It can be accessed by road from either of these towns, by boat through Caleta Gonzalo, or from Argentina via the Paso de Menendez. Pumalin was designated by the government as a nature sanctuary in 2005 and is Chile's largest private nature reserve. There are many trails for hiking and grounds for camping amid untouched Valdivian temperate rainforest that is home to thousands of species and sub-species of flora and fauna, as well as some of the last remaining Alerce trees (one of the oldest species on Earth!). The Park is accessible by car from Chaiten and by ferry from Hornopiren, docking at Caleta Gonzalo at the very centre of the Park.

description.web: Puerto Toro is a very small pier for boats and kayaks, allowing people to explore the Serrano Glacier, at the northern end of the Last Hope Sound.

description.web: Puerto Williams is located in Tierra del Fuego, Patagonia, on Isla Navarino facing the Beagle Channel and is the gateway to the famous Dientes de Navarino trek. The town increased in size as a Chilean naval base and now has grown to include several small supermarkets, a handful of restaurants, a bakery, bar and a museum. Puerto Williams is sometimes considered the southernmost city in the world, a title that is disputed by the larger Ushuaia, located on the opposite, northern side of the Beagle Channel in Argentinian territory. Daily flights run from Punta Arenas to Puerto Williams throughout the year.There's a secluded all-inclusive lodge called the Lakutaia that's a perfect base if you'd prefer to explore from comfort.

description.web: Puerto Pirámides is a small town on the Peninsula Valdés, within the Nature Reserve and UNESCO World Heritage Site. A small seaside place, from Piramides you can go kayaking out in the bay and around Golfo Nuevo and go whale watching to see Humpback and Orca whales from December to March.

description.web: Punta del Este is a world-renowned, glamorous beach resort city and peninsula located on the Atlantic coast of southeastern Uruguay. Often called the "Monaco" or "St. Tropez of South America," it is famous for its stunning beaches, vibrant nightlife, luxury hotels, casinos, and upscale dining, attracting a mix of international tourists and celebrities.

description.web: Punta Delgada, at the southern tip of Peninsula Valdes is home to one of the biggest sea lion colonies in South America and the beach is exclusive to customers at the Hotel Faro Punta Delgada. This beautiful spot is one of the many points of interest along the coast on the Peninsula and can be reached by car via a drive of about 2 hours from Puerto Piramides.

description.web: This beautiful and secluded beach can be found on Peninsula Valdes in the province of Chubut in Argentina. 'Conos', meaning cones, refers to the cone-like hillocks in the area. Conos is unlike many other beaches, in that it is rich with the fossils of local sea life dating back millions of years. A fantastic place for kayaking, Conos is one of the many top spots in a kayaking trip in the area. Find out more about kayaking in Patagonia.

description.web: Nearest major airport to Torres del Paine National Park and three hours south of Puerto Natales. You can also get from Punta Arenas to Ushuaia on Tierra del Fuego via a dramatic 12 hour bus journey. Daily flights from Santiago, and from Puerto Montt. Flights to the Falkland Islands leave from here every Saturday.

description.web: Established in 1848, Punta Arenas is the capital of the Magallan Province in southern Chilean Patagonia. It is believed that the town was named 'Sandy Point' by a British sea captain called John Byron, who sailed to Patagonia and claimed to have seen giants inhabiting the land. The name was later changed to the Spanish Punta Arenas . Find out h ow to get from Ushuaia to Punta Arenas. Gateway to Torres del Paine Many travellers visiting Torres del Paine National Park fly to Punta Arenas airport (Carlos Ibáñez del Campo International (PUQ)), which lies around 13 miles north of Punta Arenas and serves Chilean Patagonia. The main airlines operating here are LAN Chile and Sky Airline, which offer regular flights from Santiago and Puerto Montt. Once in Punta Arenas, travellers then take the 3-hour bus journey directly to Puerto Natales, a small town just outside Torres del Paine. Puerto Natales is known for its beautiful fjord, the Seno Ultima Esperanza which is perfect for kayaking. Punta Arenas is a good place to relax and prepare for your W Trek or Full Circuit trek in Torres del Paine with a reasonable range of hotels and restaurants. Adventure Cruises As a major sea port, Punta Arenas also acts as a departure point for Patagonia cruises . There are several options, including: Cruises through the Chilean fjords between Punta Arenas and are a fantastic way of either arriving at the trekking heart of Patagonia, or of departing for the north after a W Trek or Full Circuit trek Cruises to Ushuaia, Tierra del Fuego and Cape Horn offer an incredible way of exploring the Magellan Straits sailed by Darwin and getting up close to Magellanic penguins, hanging glaciers and the wild and remote landscape loved by adventurous trekkers. Accommodation It is common when travelling through Punta Arenas to need overnight accommodation, either due to the timing of flights and cruises or simply to break up your journey. We have shortlisted a selection of recommended hotels to make it easier for you to find the place that best fits your needs and budget.

description.web: Just 20 miles from the stunning San Rafael Glacier in the pristine region of Aysen, Punta Leopardos is one of the stops during a 5-6 day trip along the southern Chilean fjords and inlets. The area itself is very peaceful and tranquil, with quiet waters, trees and birds. Find out more about Adventure cruises in Patagonia >>

description.web: The nature reserve of Punta Loma is located just outside Puerto Madryn. It is a popular place for spotting wildlife.

description.web: Punta Piramides or Piramides Point is a rocky outcrop in the bay of Puerto Piramides, which is characteristic of the sandy rock found throughout Peninsula Valdes. Punta Piramides is just one of the landmarks you could visit during a kayaking trip on the Peninsula. Find out more about visiting Peninsula Valdes >>

description.web: Punta Norte at the very northern tip of Peninsula Valdes is around 77 kilometres from Puerto Piramides, the main town on the Peninsula. In Punta Norte is home to a multitude of Elephant seals and Magellanic penguins that live here throughout the year and in great number between December and April (breeding season). This part of the Peninsula is usually best seen by car, and can be reached along the Ruta 30 before driving on the paved roads (with a speed limit of 60km per hour). After seeing Punta Norte, you may want to take the route along the coast south to Caleta Valdes a lagoon formed by a solid 30-kilometer-long bar spreading from North to South and home to a huge colony of Elephant seals and a fantastic place to watch Orcas (Killer whales) hunt seals from February to April. Find out more about visiting Peninsula Valdes >>

description.web: This remote lighthouse is found on the Peninsula Valdes in the province of Chubut in Argentina. Peninsula Valdes attracts thousands of tourists each year keen to jump in boats to go whale watching. If you're a more adventurous type, you may want to visit this beautiful region by kayak, as you'll get up close to the whales and paddle alongside sea lion colonies. Find out more about kayaking in Patagonia.

description.web: Puyuhuapi is a small town in the northern section of the Carretera that is famous for its nearby hot springs, with various resorts to stay in an enjoy them amid beautiful landscapes. It is also an access point into Queulat National Park. It is a quaint town with German architectural influence, framed by high mountains covered with forests. Puyuhuapi is jjust 20km from Queulat National Park.

description.web: Punta Tombo is close to Peninsula Valdes in the northern part of Argentinian Patagonia. Here you'll find the world's largest colony of Magellanic penguins, with around 1 million penguins roosting here each year from September to April. Tours to see the penguins depart from nearby Trelew and Puerto Madryn regularly between October and March.

description.web: Puritama Hot Springs are a series of eight large, natural thermal pools located at the bottom of a canyon in the Atacama Desert, Chile. The mineral-rich, warm waters are a popular tourist destination for relaxation and rejuvenation, offering a surreal oasis in the arid landscape.

description.web: Quilquico is a small village on Chiloé Island in Chile. It is visited as part of a horse-riding day trip from the Tierra Chiloé Hotel.

description.web: Ramaditas Mountain Lodge is located on the edge of Laguna Ramaditas, in Bolivia, not far from the border with Chile.

description.web: Refugia Chiloé is a boutique spa island hotel resort where intrepid adventure vacations are coupled with comfort. Immerse yourself in the best of this archipelago, which is awash in verdant pastures, dramatic coastlines and scenic clifftops.

description.web: This fjord, in the green and largely undiscovered region of Aysen, is one of the stops during a 6-day adventure cruise around southern Patagonia's glaciers. It's here that guest enjoy bathing in the hot springs in covered or open air pools with temperatures ranging across 36º, 32º and 30º Celcius. You can also enjoy the calm and tranquil fjord which is bordered by green forests and snow capped mountains in the distance. Find out more about visiting the Quitralco Fjord on board an adventure cruise in Patagonia >>

description.web: Located in the heart of Pumalin National Park in Chile's Patagonian Lake District, Quintupeo Fjord was known amongst locals as the hiding place of the German battleship 'The Dresden' during the Battle of the Falkland Islands in 1914. In this almost untouched place, kayaking is the best way to make the most of its waterfalls, huge sloping granite walls and close up views of its abundant trees and vegetation. It's a truly wild place to camp and everything is still and quiet save for a pod of austral dolphins or sea lions sunbathing nearby. Not far from the fjo r d you'll find the picturesque Island of Llancahué, where you can relax in its 52°C hot springs.

description.web: Home to 1 500 square km of glacier-topped peaks and evergreen forests, the area was originally explored in the 1700s by Spanish colonisers in search of the City of the Caesars. These days it is famous for its Hanging Glacier.

description.web: Rainbow Valley (Valle Arcoiris) is a geological marvel in the Atacama Desert near San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, famous for its hills and canyons that are naturally painted with vibrant stripes of red, green, white, and yellow from various mineral deposits, creating a landscape that looks like a painted canvas.

description.web: Refugio Agostino Rocca is located at 1400m, very close to the Paso de Las Nubes - the Pass of the Clouds.There are 80 beds in this modern refuge, split into ten rooms containing eight single beds each.

description.web: This refugio is located close to the impressive Salto Grande waterfall, on the northern edge of Lago Pehoé. This is an area of Torres del Paine National Park that is much less visited than those that lie on the route of the W Trek.

description.web: This is a wilderness refugio on the shores of the Río de las Vueltas owned and operated exclusively by one of Swoop's partners. It's a very peaceful place, nicely designed, and the hosts are very friendly and good cooks.When staying here, you can use kayaks provided by the refugio on the nearby Lago Cóndor and mountain bike either north to Lago del Desierto, or south towards Laguna Azul. You might choose to cycle to Hosteria el Pilar, hike up to Laguna de Los Tres, and return in a day to a very good meal and bottle of wine. To get to the refugio, there is a complimentary 40-minute transfer from El Chaltén. To find out more about Refugio Cóndor or to book your stay, see our Hotels in El Chaltén page.

description.web: Refugio El Chileno lies in Valle Ascencio in Torres del Paine, on the route of the popular W Trek. It is a place to stay on the trail that leads to the base of the Las Torres mountains, with showers, a restaurant and a small shop.

description.web: Refugio Frey is a mountain hut on the shore of Laguna Tonchek in Nahuel Huapi Naitonal Park. You can stay here on the first night of a four day hut-to-hut hike through the mountains.

description.web: One of the newest refugios, Refugio Grey is a traditional hiker's hut and is nestled amongst the trees on the shores of Lake Grey, a short walk from the Glacier Grey lookout point. It has 60 beds in dormitories, with up to eight beds each. Rooms are small and basic, but certainly do the job in providing a warm and friendly sanctuary.

description.web: Also know as Refugio Laguna Negra, this is a mountain hut on the shore of the lake of the same name. You can stay here on the third night of a four day hut-to-hut hike through the mountains of Nahuel Huapi National Park.

description.web: Also known as Refugio San Martín, this is a mountain hut beside Laguna Jakob in Nahuel Huapi National Park. You can spend the night here on the second day of a four-day hut-to-hut hike through the mountains.

description.web: This refugio lies on Rio Paine, close to Laguna Amarga in the East of Torres del Paine National Park. Away from the most popular trekking route in the park, this is a smaller refugio in a relatively quiet area. The facilities include shared bathrooms, a restaurant and a traditional 'quincho' grill area. Laguna Amarga is best for Puma Tracking in Torres del Paine. Read our guide to puma tracking in Torres del Paine

description.web: This refugio is beside Lago Nordenskjold in Torres del Paine National Park and it lies on the route of the W Trek not far from the French Valley. It is relatively small with just 36 beds, making it one of the most sociable refugios in the park. In addition there are private cabins away from the main building beside a waterfall. The refugio has a restaurant, shop and shared bathrooms.

description.web: Refugio Otto Meiling sits between two glaciers, high on Mount Tronador, and provides shelter for those trekking on the mountain. Otto Meiling was a German-born mountaineer who achieved many first ascents in this region, including several peaks in Nahuel Huapi National Park. He built this hut in the 1950s on Mount Tronador, which he summitted 15 times, and it was later renamed after him.

description.web: The Refugio Puesto Cagliero is located in the Reserva Los Huemules in Argentina. It is next to Lago del Diablo and is used as an overnight stop on the way to ice trekking tips on Glacier Cagliero.

description.web: Refugio Paine Grande is the largest refugio on the route of the W Trek, with good-sized rooms for 100 trekkers. This refugio lies on the shore of Lago Pehoé offering great views of the lake as well as the Paine Grande mountains, which can be enjoyed from the bar. Decent portions of good food are served in the canteen and there are also lounge areas, shower rooms, a shop and even computers with internet access.

description.web: Reloncaví Fjord is located in the Chilean Lake District and is visited on a sea kayaking trip from Puerto Varas. A wide variety of wildlife inhabits the fjord including sea lions, dolphins, pelicans and penguins.

description.web: The Reserva Los Huemules is located in Argentina and is committed to the conservation of both cultural heritage and wildlife. It is home to torrent duck, Magellanic woodpecker, condor, huemul, red fox and puma.

description.web: The Alumine river is home to Brown and Rainbow trout, which can be fished by both wet and dry fly fishing. The lower part of this river runs past Estancia Huechahue, a fly-fishing and riding lodge which offers its guests guides and equipment.

description.web: You can take advantage of the large numbers of both Brown and Rainbow trout in the Collon Cura by float fishing. Beside the upper part of the river lies Estancia Huechahue, a fly-fishing and riding lodge which can provide fishing equipment adn guides for its guests.

description.web: This river winds down from the Argentinian Lake District into Lago Viedma, and is a fantastic location for kayaking, with a backdrop of forests and glaciers.

description.web: The source of Rio Blanco is Laguna Sucia, which collects water that has been fed into Laguna de los Tres by its glacier. The river eventually joins Rio Electrico and it is possible to trek along Rio Blanco from the Rio Electrico Bridge. You can also trek beside this river on the day trek to the famous viewpoint at Laguna de los Tres from El Chaltén, and it flows between two Fitz Roy base camps: Campos Rio Blanco and Poincenot.

description.web: Running past the small town of Junin de los Andes, Rio Chimehuin is the river which gave northern Patagonia its reputation as one of the world's top fly fishing destinations. You can fish the river's Brown and Rainbow trout from drift boats or by wading out into the water, and the clear waters allow for a wide range of techniques. Rio Chimehuin is easily accessible from the nearby Estancia Huechahue.

description.web: River Chico Camp is located at the top of the Río Chico Valley. It is used as a base camp from which to trek to nearby valleys, viewpoints and lagoons.

description.web: Found in the northern part of Los Glaciares National Park, the Fitz Roy River is a popular location from which to begin hikes to some of the park's main highlights including Cerro Torre. The Fitz Roy river flows through a beautiful glacial valley and through the town of El Chaltén, which is the base for many people hiking in the park.

description.web: Around 20km north of El Chaltén this is normally the drop-off point for people heading to Piedra del Fraile and the Marconi Pass. A transfer out from Chaltén will take around 30 minutes and cost £10 to £20.

description.web: Nearby the town with the same name in the Chilean Lake District, this fast-flowing river is the site of the yearly Futafest, a competition held by local white water rafting companies in the Chilean Lake District with kayaking & rafting races. It's a top spot for white water rafters from all over the world, and it's not hard to see why as rafting this river's waters is an exciting challenge. Furthermore, the river's surroundings make it a lovely place to visit even if you don't plan to white water raft. You'll find forests, mountains and lakes nearby, and if you do choose to kayak or white water raft with a local operator, you'll stay at a riverside adventure camp where you can relax in a hot tub or enjoy horse riding & trekking too. Other popular rivers for white water rafting include the Rio Manso over the border near Bariloche. Similarly to the Futaleufu it's fast-flowing currents attract thrill seekers, and it's split into 3 sections according to levels of difficulty.

description.web: Rio Gallegos is the Capital of the Province of Santa Cruz in Argentina and is found on the atlantic coast. Its has a nearby airport which supports 3-4 flights a day from Buenos Aires. This is not much of a tourist town however, it is mainly a hub for coal-shipping and wool production. Most people who visit Rio Gallegos will be passing through en route to El Calafate (5 and a half hours away), Puerto Natales (3 and a half hours away) or Ushuaia (7 and a half hours away).

description.web: A major contributory into the Lago General Carrera, the source of the Rio Ibanez lies somewhere amid the foothills of the Hudson Volcano, just north of the North Patagonian Ice Cap. Running past Cerro Castillo national Park, it flows all the way to Puerto Ibanez on the northern shore of the Lago General Carrera.

description.web: Rio Manso is a beautiful river in a wonderful setting, and its fast and furious rapids make it a great place for whitewater rafting. Rafting trips here can range from one day on the water to week-long trips, staying at lodges and campsites.

description.web: The Malleo is famous among anglers as one of the best spots in Patagonia for fishing the region's trout. Wading is the best way to reach the fish here, and this river is perfect for dry fly fishing. The river is easily accessible from the nearby Estancia Huechahue, a fishing and riding lodge which can provide its guests with equipment and guides.

description.web: The Río Negro river is a significant waterway in Argentine Patagonia, whose headwaters (the Limay and Neuquén rivers) converge within Neuquén Province before the Río Negro itself flows eastward through the province of the same name to the Atlantic Ocean. This river system is crucial for irrigation, hydroelectricity, and supports fertile agricultural valleys, particularly known for fruit production.

description.web: The mighty Palena extends from the pampas all the way to the Pacific, providing a fascinating way of exploring the hugely contrasting environments of Patagonia. it is navigable along its whole length, running past Alto Palena, La Junta, and Raul marin Balmaceda. The river was in 2010 declared a freshwater reserve, home to some outstanding salmon. The section from La Junta to Raul Marin was declared in 2009 a Heritage Route by the Ministry of National Properties. Popular activities here include white-water rafting, kayaking and canoeing, as well as fishing.

description.web: This choppy river starts in Argentina and flows across the border into Lago Tagua Tagua some 17 miles from Cochamo in the Chilean Lake District. It then flows all the way east to the Reloncavi Estuary. A great location for kayaking and horse riding, the terrain is mountainous and green, perfect for growing grapes, and the whole area has a mediterranean feel when the sun is shining.

description.web: A tributary of the famous Rio Chimehuin, Quilquihue is a smaller river offering dry fly fishing opportunities. This river can be accessed from Estancia Huechahue, a nearby lodge which can provide its guests with equipment and guides.

description.web: The source of the Rio Serrano lies in Torres del Paine National Park. It flows into the Bernardo O'Higgins national park, joining the Seno Última Esperanza at Puerto Toro. Kayaking down the Rio Serrano is a wonderful experience and for the lucky few a fitting finale to a few days of hiking. Some people choose to enter the national park via the Rio Serrano, taking a Zodiac boat down the river. One example is this 14 day trek in Torres del Paine. Also, the Serrano River is a great area for fly fishing, in the shadow of the Paine Massif. The most common fish here is the Brown trout, but you can also find some Rainbow trout and the huge Chinook Salmon, all of which can be fished by wading into the river.

It is known for its spectacular panoramic views of the Paine Massif and its location as a base for exploring the park's iconic sights.

description.web: Río Simpson is a river in the Aysén Region of Chilean Patagonia, known for its pristine waters and beautiful canyon landscapes. It is a popular destination for fly-fishing, rafting, and other aquatic sports, and flows through the Río Simpson National Reserve.

description.web: The Traful is an exclusively catch and release fly-fishing river, home to rainbow and brown trout and land-locked salmon. Some sections of the riverbank are lined with trees and shrubs. The river runs high and fast at the beginning of the season, with the level usually dropping in December but still having fast water until mid-January; it then runs slow until the first rains of the Autumn.

description.web: Rio Tunel flows down from Glaciars Rio Tunel Superior and Inferior and out into Bahia Tunel on the North West corner of Lago Viedma. You can trek beside the river on the Huemul Circuit, which is a multi-day trek starting and ending in El Chaltén.

description.web: Robinson Crusoe Lodge gives you the opportunity to explore the pristine, undiscovered area of Villa o'Higgins, north of Torres del Paine. You can choose from one of their 3 programmes: trekking new trails which weren't around a couple of years ago, ice hiking over secluded glaciers and sailing across lakes in a region as yet undiscovered by tourists. Robinson Crusoe's motto, 'return to freedom', allows you to do just that in a small group of like minded people, in a relaxed atmosphere.

description.web: Salar de Atacama is the largest salt flat in Chile, located in the heart of the Atacama Desert. This vast, shimmering white landscape is famous for its surreal appearance, highly saline lagoons like Laguna Chaxa and Laguna Cejar where you can float effortlessly, and as a critical habitat for various species of flamingos.

description.web: Salta is a delightful vibrant city in northern Argentina. Driving out from Salta gives you a great opportunity to explore the surrounding region on some stunning roads, leading you through the mountains of wondrous shades, valleys overflowing with cacti, and colonial towns of Cafayate and the Cachi. Along the way you can hike trails through oasis valleys and vineyards, where you'll be able to taste the local wines, and sleep in charming traditional manor houses surrounded by dramatic scenery.

description.web: The Saltos del Laja are huge waterfalls based in the north of Patagonia which stand at some 40 y 55 metres high. They can be found 16 miles north of the City of Los Angeles in the Bio Bio region of Chile. This waterfall and its surroundings are really beautiful and a great place to visit particularly if you're travelling along the Ruta 5 (Panamerican highway).

This impressive cascade is one of the more unusual highlights to see in the park, and few people actually visit it.

description.web: San Isidro is a town in Greater Buenos Aires. It is located 28km from the city centre and is the city’s most affluent neighbourhood. The centre of San Isidro is a historic area with cobbled streets and single-storey houses. At the heart of Plaza Mitre is the neo-gothic San Isidro Cathedral, built in 1898.

description.web: San Juan Bay (Bahía San Juan) is a historical coastal area on the Brunswick Peninsula in Chilean Patagonia. It is notable as the location of significant early Chilean settlement attempts, including the ruins of Fuerte Bulnes and Puerto Hambre, situated along the Strait of Magellan.

description.web: San Pedro is the gateway to the Atacama Desert and its only significant town for visitors. It sits on a plateau at 2,400m above sea level but the Andes rise up to over 6,000m within a few kilometres of the town creating a wonderful backdrop. It is a single storey adobe town with dirt roads. A good range of acccommodation options some great places to eat many of which are set around a central courtyard with an open fire.

description.web: Santiago airport (SCL) is Chile's biggest international airport and the access point for any trip to Chilean Patagonia. The airport is located between the beautiful port city of Valparaiso and the city of Santiago itself.

description.web: Santiago is the capital of Chile and the gateway to Chilean Patagonia's mountain peaks, glacial valleys, and coastal fjords. International visitors to Chile will fly into Santiago airport and may wish to spend some time in the capital or in the nearby port city of Valparaiso. A guided or unguided walking tour is the perfect way to explore Santiago's historical and cultural landmarks in an afternoon. Find out what to do in Santiago.

description.web: Close to Punta Arenas, Seno Otway is a fantastic place to see a Patagonian penguin colony, which makes its home here each year from October to March.

description.web: The Seno Moyano, or Moyano Sound, branches off from Lago Viedma and is located in the Los Glaciares National Park.
description.quote: The Seno Moyano, or Moyano Sound, branches off from Lago Viedma and is located in the Los Glaciares National Park.

description.web: Seno Última Esperanza gets its name from Captain Juan de Ladrillero, who in 1557 went searching for the western entrance to the Strait of Magellan. After several weeks of searching, and in desperate need of food and water, he eventually found this fjord and was able to stock up on provisions in what is now Puerto Natales. Out of his joy at finding what he thought was the Strait, he named the fjord 'Seno Última Esperanza' or 'Sound of Last Hope'. A fun way to explore this fjord is by catching the ferry from Glaciar Serrano, just on the border of Torres del Paine National Park, down the Serrano river. On its way back to Puerto Natales, the ferry stops at Estancia Perales for you to enjoy a delicious lamb asado, before you continue on for the 2-hour journey back to Puerto Natales harbour. A handful of operators offer kayaking trips in the Seno Ultima Esperanza. This is a peaceful location where you can paddle up to a waterfall and camp out on the fjord's green banks.

description.web: Serrano Camp is a designated camping area located near the Serrano River and the southern entrance of Torres del Paine National Park in Chilean Patagonia. It serves as a popular and convenient base for trekkers and visitors exploring the park's iconic trails and landscapes.

description.web: The Serrano Glacier lies on the border of Patagonia's most popular destination and national park - Torres del Paine . The glacier descends steeply into a lagoon surrounded by pine trees and is easily accessed with a 5-10 minute walk from the small pier and campsite near Puerto Toro.

description.web: Sierra Dorotea Hill (also known as Cerro Dorotea) is a prominent hill located just outside Puerto Natales in Chilean Patagonia. It offers incredible panoramic views of the city, the Ultima Esperanza Fjord, and a vast expanse of the Patagonian steppe, making it a popular spot for short hikes, horseback riding, or 4x4 tours to enjoy the scenery.

description.web: The South Shetland Islands are a group of 20 islands and islets that were first reached in February 1819. The Islands are also the first piece of land after crossing the Drake Passage from Patagonia and before reaching Antarctica. The Islands are teaming with wildlife and are a must-see for anyone travelling on an Antarctic cruise. Here you can expect to see huge penguin rookeries and beaches teaming with seals. On King George Island, you can see cute Adélie and Chinstrap Penguins, as well as Kelp Gulls, Blue-eyed Cormorants, Antarctic Terns and Southern Giant Petrels. This is also where the Chilean and Argentinian goverments have their research bases.

description.web: Sollipulli volcano is an active stratovolcano located in the Araucanía Region of the Chilean Andes, notably distinguished by its large, ice-filled caldera. This unique feature makes it a challenging and rewarding destination for trekkers and mountaineers seeking a remote Patagonian adventure. 2,282 m (7,487 ft).

description.web: Whilst not the biggest of the major glaciers in Los Glaciares National Park, Spegazzini Glacier is a hugely impressive sight, if for no other reason than the sheer size of its wall, which can tower as high as 135 metres (440 feet). Where is it? Glaciar Sepgazzini sits on Lago Argentino, close to other major glacial sights in Los Glaciares such as Perito Moreno and Glaciar Upsala The closest main town is El Chaltén - a small hikers' haven nestled amid the mountains, in the shadow of Mount Fitz Roy How to see it: Accessible only by boat, you can see this glacier along with several others by weaving between the moving icebergs of Lago Argentino The area is served by El Calafate's hotels and airport, and by the various places to stay in El Chaltén Find out more about Patagonia's glaciers.
