description.web: Tamango National Park is a protected area in the Aysén Region of Chilean Patagonia, primarily known as a crucial habitat for the endangered Huemul (Andean deer). The park offers diverse landscapes ranging from Patagonian steppe to lenga forests, providing excellent opportunities for trekking and wildlife observation near the town of Cochrane.

description.web: The capital city of Chile’s Araucanía region, Temuco is an important gateway to both the Chilean Lake District and the adventure capital of Pucón, as well as being the main access point for Conguíllo National Park. For Chileans it’s known best as the city where their national poet Pablo Neruda grew up and had some of his earliest poetry published. Temuco was founded in 1881 in the heartlands of Mapuche territory. It’s complicated colonial history is on display in the city’s Plaza de Armas Aníbal Pinto , named for the president who ordered the town’s creation. In the plaza’s centre stands a massive statue called Homenaje a la Regíon de la Araucanía (Tribute to the Araucanía Region), which shows a female Mapuche shaman with a raised drum on a rocky plinth surrounded on four sides by the Mapuche leader Kallfulifan, the conquistador-poet Alonso de Ercilla, a soldier of the pacification and a modern colonist. The excellent Museo Regional de la Araucanía has a strong focus on Mapuche culture. On the northern edge of Temuco, the Monumento Natural Cerro Ñielol is a 90 hectare reserve of native forest, on the spot where Mapuche leaders ceded their territory to the colonists for the founding of the town. The city is a major transport hub. Temuco’s Araucanía Airport (code ZCO) is 21km south of the city. From here it’s around a 90 minute flight to Santiago. Connections to Puerto Montt are also routed through Santiago; there are no direct flights from Temuco. Pucón is 105km south of Temuco – about a 90 minute drive. There are direct long distance buses to most cities in Chile, as well services to Bariloche in Argentina.

description.web: Tepuhueico Park is located on the west on Chiloé Island and can be visited on a day trip from Castro. There are fantastic opportunities for hiking in the park and it's home to both pudu and Darwin's fox.

description.web: The Capillas de Marmol (the Marble Caves), also known as Catedral de Marmol (the Marble Cathedral), is an inredible natural attraction that draws hundreds of visitors every year to the little town of Puerto Tranquilo (from where boats and kayaks can be rented with which to visit). Created by the erosive effect of the blue water of Lago General Carrera lapping at the stone, the Cathedral looks like a beautiful piece of sculpted artwork.

description.web: The Remota Hotel is located on the shore of Seno Ultima Esperanza, just outside of the small town of Puerto Natales, which lies on the edge of Torres del Paine National Park. The hotel, which occupies an old agricultural building, has comfortable rooms and stylish architecture. It is open all year round and offers a range of excursions into the national park. Find out more and check availability for the Remota Hotel.

description.web: The Singular is a luxury hotel in Puerto Bories, around a two hour drive from Torres del Paine National Park. Despite being quite a distance outside of this national park, the hotel does offer trekking trips to the famous trails of Torres del Paine. The hotel's all inclusive packages include a variety of excursions in the surrounding landscape, as well as comfortable rooms and suites with views of the Last Hope Sound, and meals in the Singular's unique restaurant. Find out more and check availability for The Singular Hotel.

description.web: Situated just outside Torres del Paine National Park to the East, Tierra Patagonia is a beautifully designed luxury hotel with stunning views over the park. The hotel provides excursions to all the main highlights of Torres del Paine, as well as the less visited sights that lie well off the beaten track, with experienced enthusiastic guides. Other offerings of the hotel include a spa, restaurant and open bar. >>> Find out more about Tierra Patagonia

description.web: This luxurious lodge is located in the heart of a working cattle ranch in the Argentinian Lake District. Fly fishing is the main activity on offer here, but it is also possible to take part in horse riding and hiking. The lodge has excellent facilities and provides good quality food and drink, and with just 9 rooms in the lodge, you'll receive a very personalised service.

description.web: Tolhuaca volcano is a stratovolcano located in the Andes Mountains of southern Chile, known for its steep, glacially-eroded slopes and for dominating the landscape views in the nearby Tolhuaca National Park. 2,806 m (9,206 ft)

description.web: Torres del Paine is a world-famous national park in Chilean Patagonia, renowned for its dramatic granite peaks, massive glaciers, bright blue lakes, and abundant wildlife, offering some of the best multi-day trekking in the world.

description.web: Found in the Chubut Province on the eastern coast of Argentinian Patagonia, Trelew is one of the Welsh cities in Argentina and has a large and recently refurbished airport servicing the region, with flights to Buenos Aires taking just under 2 hours. Trelew itself is a large industrial city processing wool and was founded in 1886 by Welsh settlers who also established many other towns and cities in the area such as Esquel, Gaiman and Rawson. There are some wonderful spots to visit not far from Trelew including the Peninsula Valdes, a wildlife haven for whales, penguins and seals, which was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1999. In order to reach Puerto Piramides, the only small town within the Peninsula, it's best to take the bus to Puerto Madryn (45 minutes) and from there to Puerto Piramides (30 minutes). Find out more about visiting Peninsula Valdes >>

description.web: Torre Sur is the highest of Las Torres, the three granite spires from which Torres del Paine National Park takes its name. On the most popular trekking routes in the park you can hike to a stunning lookout point onto these peaks.

rows.component_name: Torres del Paine look-out (via Valle Ascensio)

description.web: Trekking up Valle Ascencio to arrive at the Torres del Paine lookout is the highlight of the W Circuit or Full Circuit in Torres del Paine National park. Located at the East of the park, this viewpoint looks straight out onto the three granite 'torres' from which the park takes its name and beneath them, a still grey-blue lake.After having made the 2-hour journey by bus or private transfer into Torres del Paine National Park from Puerto Natales the day before, this day-trek up to the look-out (which is included in almost every operator's itinerary) starts from the base of Ascencio Valley, at Refugio Las Torres/Camping las Torres or Hotel Las Torres.The hike up to the look-out is considered by many as one of the most difficult days on the Full Circuit, alon g with Paso John Garner , as you ascend some 800 metres. It takes roughly 4 hours to reach the Torres del Paine viewpoint from the start of Valle Ascencio, a pretty windy place to trek in Patagonian summer so make sure to bring a windproof jacket if you're there between October to March. It's also important to bear in mind that the last 45 minutes up to the look-out are a steep uphill climb over rocks and sandy terrain, and many hikers take trekking poles to help their knees on the way back down. After trekking up to the look-out, hard-core climbers can continue up along Valle Silencio, past Campamento Japones and through dense rainforest for views of 'los Cuernos' mountains, Escudo (the Shield) and Fortaleza (the Fortress), as well as the back of the spectacular granite spires, Las Torres.

rows.component_name: Torres del Paine National Park Administration Centre

description.web: The primary administrative headquarters for Torres del Paine National Park in Chilean Patagonia, managed by the National Forestry Corporation (CONAF). This main office and visitor center is located in the Lago Toro sector, about 145 km from Puerto Natales and 33 km from the park's main access gate (Sarmiento gate), providing essential services, information, and environmental education.

description.web: Tyndall Glacier or Geike Glacier is one of the largest glaciers in the Southern Patagonian Ice Field. It is located in the Torres del Paine National Park, Chile. The glacier has its main calving front in Geikie Lake and like its neighbor, Grey Glacier, it has been significantly retreating for the last years.

description.web: Tronador, 3,478m, is an extinct volcano on the border between Argentina and Chile, near Bariloche. It’s a popular mountaineering destination and in both the Nahuel Huapi National Park in Argentina and the Vicente Pérez Rosales National Park in Chile.

description.web: These small islands lie in the Magellan Straits and can be seen on an adventure cruise. Excursions on Zodiac boats take you up to the Tucker Islets to see the native Magellanic penguins.

description.final: These small islands lie in the Magellan Straits and can be seen on an adventure cruise. Excursions on Zodiac boats take you up to the Tucker Islets to see the native Magellanic penguins.

description.web: About the Glacier Named after Uppsala University (spelt at the time with only one ' p '), in Sweden - the University sponsored some of the first glaciological exploration of the region Upsala is well known for its rapid retreat over recent decades and is commonly used as evidence of global warming Is even bigger than the more famous and accesible Perito Moreno Where is it? Upsala is a large valley glacier found in Argentina's Los Glaciares National Park ("The Glaciers" National Park) It flows from the Southern Patagonian Ice Field, which also feeds the famous Perito Moreno glacier The glacier's terminus is at the shore of Lago Argentino How to see it: Great for day visits, it can be combined with a tour of a nearby Patagonian estancia from which you can go for a guided hike or 4x4 adventure into the mountains to panoramic viewpoints. A popular destination for travellers, it is served by the hotels of El Chaltén and the airport in El Calafate Incorporate it into a broader exploration of Los Glaciares and Patagonia More Details >>

description.web: Ushuaia is the access town to the Beagle Channel and the great hiking and kayaking opportunities available in Tierra del Fuego. Many travellers stay here before going to see the island's many sea lion colonies and penguin rookeries, or hopping off on a 2 to 3 day kayaking trip around Gable Island in the Beagle Channel. Antarctic Port Ushuaia is even better known as the port from which most Antarctic cruises depart for Antarctic sea adventures of up to 20 days. The cruises first cross the Drake Passage before reaching the South Shetland Islands or they sail via South Georgia and Sandwich Islands. Instead of setting out from the port of Ushuaia, some cruises start off in the Falkland Islands, spending a day or two enjoying its markets, restaurants, flora and fauna, before heading towards the coast of Antarctica. Other ships instead offer a fly and cruise option, with flights from the Chilean town of Punta Arenas straight through to an Antarctic research base on King George Island. Accommodation This is the perfect place to stay before you set out on your adventures in Tierra del Fuego or Antarctica. Find hotels in Ushuaia, and check availability for your dates. If you're heading on to explore Torres del Paine, read our blog post to find out about getting to Punta Arenas from Ushuaia.

description.web: Ushuaia is the southernmost city in the world, and the access point for almost all trips to Tierra del Fuego, as well as Antarctic Cruises. Flights to/from El Calafate and Buenos Aires (AEP). You can cross from here to Chilean Tierra del Fuego with a boat trip across the Beagle Channel.

description.web: Uyuni is a city in southwest Bolivia. It's the most convenient place from which to access the Uyuni Salt Flats.There is an airport just outside the city which has flights to La Paz and Sucre.

description.web: Andorra Valley is one of the hikes popular in Tierra del Fuego, especially for people based in the southernmost city in the world, Ushuaia. Here you'll see a fantastic mountain range and also have views out over Ushuaia and the Beagle Channel beyond. Find out more about discovering Tierra del Fuego .

description.web: Valle Carbajal (Carbajal Valley) is a beautiful, U-shaped glacial valley in the Fuegian Andes of Tierra del Fuego, Argentina, near the city of Ushuaia, which is famous for its picturesque peat bogs and as a popular destination for hiking, trekking, and winter sports.

description.web: Valle Chacabuco provides an incredible landscape - a rare east-west valley, it showcases the transition from Andean peaks through to the grasslands of the steppe. Valle Chacabuco is at the heart of the planned "Patagonia National Park". The park has been under development since 2004 and is this year (2014) opening to the public (although not yet a "National" Park).

description.web: The Uyuni Salt Flats are the largest in the world. They sit at around 12,000ft/3,665m above sea level and cover a vast 3,900 miles²/10,000km².

description.web: The Bader Valley lies between the Cuernos and Las Torres, the dominant peaks of Torres del Paine National Park. The path up this valley is nothing like the main trails of the popular W Trek - it's more of a little track, and the park rangers don't let people head up here without a guide. The route is challenging in parts and not always clear, but once you clear the Nirre trees you're rewarded with fantastic views of the beautiful Lago Nordenskjold. There is a small camp at the top and a makeshift hut used by the climbers. You can carry on from here to the base of Cuerno Norte and a glacial lagoon. See our off-the-beaten track guide for more on the hidden valleys and passes of Torres del Paine.

description.web: A hard 4 and a half hour slog up from the Torres del Paine look-out point, Valle del Silencio is really only for climbers with an appetite for a tough challenge. We’ve only come across a handful of operators that will take you to Valle Silencio and Valle Bader (in between Valle Ascencio and Valle Frances), and you do need a guide for these.

description.web: Where to find it Torres del Paine National Park, Chile What is it? Valle Frances (the French Valley) is a deep valley between mountains in Torres del Paine and is one of the main hiking attractions in the national park. It is dominated by a magnificent hanging glacier, Glaciar Frances, beech forests and the French River.It takes roughly two hours to trek into the valley before you get your first glimpse of the glacier and you can hear the rumble of small avalanches in the distance and watch ice calving from its face. How can I see it? You will hike the French Valley on Torres del Paine's two most famous multi-day hikes, the Full Circuit and the W Trek. It's also possible to do it as a day hike as part of a series of day trips in Torres del Paine, returning to a comfortable base each night.On the Full Circuit you typically approach the French Valley from the east, starting from the nearest refugio, Paine Grande. On the W Trek you'd most likely start from the west, trekking from nearby refugio cuernos. The weather is famously temperamental here, and a thick mist can descend making it impossible to reach the end of the valley. However if you do make it up to the end of the valley, expect spectacular views of Cerro Cota (2000m) and Cerro Catedral (2200m), a mountain which is said to resemble a cathedral facade. Find out more about... The W Trek The Full Circuit Hiking in Torres del Paine

description.web: This boulder-filled valley is a dramatic place to trek and there are stunning views from here, including Mount Fitz Roy and the Marconi Glacier. Trekking into this valley requires a guide and it is much tougher than the main hiking trail along the neighbouring Rio Electrico Valley, but the experience is well worth the effort.

description.web: The Pingo Valley lies to the west of Lago Grey in Torres del Paine National Park and is visited by very few people, which is wonderful for the Huemul deer and the few people who get out there. The initial trek into the valley is pretty easy going and well marked, and you'll come across a couple of impressive waterfalls. The first section is through an open valley and then you'll pass through a lenga forest. Once established in the valley, you can explore the Pingo Glacier and the Zapata Glacier (which lies right on the edge of the Ice Cap) from a basecamp in the valley. However, a guide is definitely needed. Tom was trekking out here in 2017 and didn't see a soul the whole time he was. Beware of the wild baguales and the mosquitos!

description.web: Chile's lively, bustling historic port city is famous for its eclectic mix of UNESCO protected architecture, its multi-coloured houses, turn of the century funiculars that still transport people up to the surrounding hills, world-class street art and delicious fresh seafood. Visit the house of the Noble Prize winner Pablo Neruda or spend a day visiting the vineyards of the near by Casablanca Valley.

description.web: Tierra Mayor Valley is a beautiful place to trek in Argentinian Tierra del Fuego. At the start of the valley you have spectacular views of the mountain ranges surrounding you, which are usually covered in snow. People usually trek there on their way up the Paso 5 Hermanos or 'Pass of the 5 Brothers'. Find out more about trekking in Tierra del Fuego or visiting the nearest city, Ushuaia, the last point before Antarctica.

description.web: The Ventisquero Colgante Waterfall (Hanging Glacier Waterfall) is a spectacular and massive waterfall in Queulat National Park in Chilean Patagonia. It is a stunning natural wonder formed by a huge hanging glacier melting and plunging thousands of feet down a cliff face, creating a dramatic and powerful waterfall.

description.web: Also known as Glaciar Chico, this glacier feeds into Lago Chico, which in turn runs into the southern branch of Lago O'Higgins.

description.web: Patagonia's most famous ski resort, just 19km from Bariloche Villa Catedral is inside the Nahuel Huapi National Park in the Argentinian Lake District. As well as skiing, you can also set out from here on a 4 day hut-to-hut hike through the nearby mountains in the heart of Nahuel Huapi National Park.

description.web: Villa Cerro Castillo is a small farming town located in the Aysén region of Chile. It's used as a base for treks into the Cerro Castillo National Reserve.

description.web: A small town founded in 1966, located in the Aysen region in the southern part of Chile.

description.web: Villa O'Higgins is a Chilean town at the Southern end of the Carretera Austral. It's actually only about 60 miles North of El Chaltén. The town, the lake that it sits on, and the National Park that stretches all the way down to Torres del Paine is named after the Chilean Independence leader Bernardo o Higgins.

description.web: The small upmarket resort town of Villa La Angostura sits on the northern finger of Lake Nahuel Huapi in Argentina's Lake District. It's a very picturesque place full of wooden alpine architecture, and offers a glimpse of what Bariloche used to look like before it began to grow (and has almost as many high end chocolate shops. The town has some excellent restaurants and a well-run tourist office. The town attracts local tourists year-round. In the winter, nearby Cerro Bayo is a boutique-sized ski and snowboarding resort. In the summer there are plenty of hiking opportunities, including to the waterfall of Cascada Río Bonito and through the woods to the blue waters of Laguna Verde . A particular highlight is the pocket-sized Arrayanes National Park on the Quetrihue Peninsula. The park is a half-day 12km hike from the town, but it's a popular activity to hire bikes for the trip along the well-marked trail. Locals like to recount the (sadly apocryphal) story that rust red bark of the arrayán trees here were the original inspiration for the forest in the Disney film Bambi . Villa La Angostura is 83km north of Bariloche, a 75-minute drive along RN40. The same road continues north to San Martín de los Andes, a further two hours and 108km away, following the tremendously scenic Route of the Seven Lakes (Rua de los Siete Lagos)

Locals like to recount the (sadly apocryphal) story that rust red bark of the arrayán trees here were the original inspiration for the forest in the Disney film Bambi . Villa La Angostura is 83km north of Bariloche, a 75-minute drive along RN40. The same road continues north to San Martín de los Andes, a further two hours and 108km away, following the tremendously scenic Route of the Seven Lakes (Rua de los Siete Lagos)
description.final: The small upmarket resort town of Villa La Angostura sits on the northern finger of Lake Nahuel Huapi in Argentina's Lake District. It's a very picturesque place full of wooden alpine architecture, and offers a glimpse of what Bariloche used to look like before it began to grow (and has almost as many high end chocolate shops. The town has some excellent restaurants and a well-run tourist office. The town attracts local tourists year-round. In the winter, nearby Cerro Bayo is a boutique-sized ski and snowboarding resort. In the summer there are plenty of hiking opportunities, including to the waterfall of Cascada Río Bonito and through the woods to the blue waters of Laguna Verde . A particular highlight is the pocket-sized Arrayanes National Park on the Quetrihue Peninsula. The park is a half-day 12km hike from the town, but it's a popular activity to hire bikes for the trip along the well-marked trail. Locals like to recount the (sadly apocryphal) story that rust red bark of the arrayán trees here were the original inspiration for the forest in the Disney film Bambi . Villa La Angostura is 83km north of Bariloche, a 75-minute drive along RN40. The same road continues north to San Martín de los Andes, a further two hours and 108km away, following the tremendously scenic Route of the Seven Lakes (Rua de los Siete Lagos)

description.web: Villa Traful is a hamlet on the shore of Lake Traful. It is located in the Nahuel Huapi National Park on the Road of the Seven lakes, 60km from Villa La Angostura and 100km from Bariloche. It consists of about 80 houses, built in traditional Alpine-Andine architecture that combines wood with stone.

description.web: The sophisticated Viña del Mar is possibly the country's most revered seaside resort. Filled with lush parks, beautiful avenues and an attractive promenade. It's popular with both Chileans and foreigners during the summer months from December to February.

description.web: Villarino Beach is located in the San José Gulf on Pensinsula Valdes. It is the end point of our three-day kayaking trip.
description.quote: Villarino Beach is located in the San José Gulf on Pensinsula Valdes. It is the end point of our three-day kayaking trip.
description.final: Villarino Beach is located in the San José Gulf on Pensinsula Valdes. It is the end point of our three-day kayaking trip.

description.web: Vincente Pérez Rosales National Park is located in Los Lagos region of Llanquihue in Chile. The park covers 2,530 square km and its western entrance is near Ensenada.
description.quote: Vincente Pérez Rosales National Park is located in Los Lagos region of Llanquihue in Chile. The park covers 2,530 square km and its western entrance is near Ensenada.

description.web: Also known as Mount Hudson, this is the site of one of the 20th Century's largest eruptions in 1991. Some activity was detected in 2011 and the Chilean government was quick to put in place safety precautions and evacuate the surrounding areas.

description.web: Volcan Lanin , 3,776m, can be tackled in 2 days, plus 2 days of travel to/from (nearest town is San Martin de Los Andes). On the first day you will practice some of the skills you'll be using on Day 2, summit day. Lanin sits on the Chilean-Argentinian border and offers fantastic views across the Andes the Chilean volcanoes. You can tackle Lanin between December and April (or possibly July-October as part of a ski touring trip). Contact us to find out about tours and guides for your dates.

description.web: The reserve's focal point. Slightly northeast of town, it dates from the late Pleistocene but erupted as recently as 1933, almost simultaneously with nearby Volcan Llaima, and lava flows spilled down its northestern flanks in 1990. Trails to nearby Cerro Cautin (2.5 hours) and Lonquimay's summit start here, and Sendero de Chile rounds Lonquimay before decending into town and then continuing toward the Sierra Nevada and Conguillo; a new trekking map, for sale at La Suizandina will make hiking here easier. 2,865 m (9,400 ft)

description.web: Chile's most active volcano, Villarrica is a cauldron of bubbling lava and venting steam that's erupted dozens of times, including a major 1971 event that expelled 30 million cubic meters of lava in a flow that spread over 14 kilometres. Rising above the lake and town of the same name, Volcan Villarrica is climbed relatively often, with guided expeditions from nearby Pucon. In the winter, there is a ski resort on the northern slopes of the volcano.

description.web: Mountain camp at 2400m. Sleep here and make preparations for the trek to the summit of Lanín Volcano.

description.web: This fascinating bay is one of the spots visited on an adventure cruise from Ushuaia to Punta Arenas, and vice versa. This cruise is the only way to get here, so it's a beautifully quiet and peaceful place. Not only is it a picturesque spot that looks out over the Beagle Channel, but Wulaia is also an archaeological site with remains from the early settlement of the Yaghan peoples. Find out more about visiting Wulaia Bay on board a Patagonian Adventure Cruise.

description.web: The Weber Bridge is located at the north of Lake Toro in Torres del Paine. It is the end point of the 14km Lazo-Weber Trail.

description.web: Situated on Lago Yelcho, accommodation is available in a hotel with 8 bedrooms, 6 cabins and a covered campsite. From here you have access to the famous fly fishing on Lago Yelcho, as well as other activities and excursions in the area.

description.web: Zapata camp is located in Torres del Paine National Park. It is a basic campsite, used as a base from which to explore the Ichthyosaurus graveyard and to climb the summit of Cerro Zapata.

description.web: The Zapata Valley is located in Torres del Paine National Park and can be entered from Lake Grey. Few trekkers visit this valley.

description.web: Laguna Cóndor is a small lagoon located in the Los Glaciares region of Argentina. It is fed by the Río Cañadon de los Toros and sits at an altitude of 450m.

description.web: Laguna Nimez is located on the north side of El Calafate town in Patagonia, Argentina. It is home to many indigenous birds, such as Chilean flamingos, Andean ruddy ducks and Magellanic plovers, with over 130 recorded species being sighted.

description.web: This is the house of pioneer Andreas Madsen. On a visit here, you will learn about the history of the Madsen family and the challenges faced by them during their everyday life in this estancia over a century ago.

description.web: The La Leona Petrified Forest is located on the bank of Río La Leona in the Los Glaciares region of Argentina.
description.quote: The La Leona Petrified Forest is located on the bank of Río La Leona in the Los Glaciares region of Argentina.
description.final: The La Leona Petrified Forest is located on the bank of Río La Leona in the Los Glaciares region of Argentina.

description.web: The Río La Leona flows through the eastern part of the Los Glaciares National Park. It starts at the southeastern part of Lago Viedma and finishes at Lago Argentino, about 50km (31 miles) away.
description.quote: The Río La Leona flows through the eastern part of the Los Glaciares National Park. It starts at the southeastern part of Lago Viedma and finishes at Lago Argentino, about 50km (31 miles) away.

description.web: Laguna Los Tempanos, or Iceberg Bay in English, is located on the northwestern side of Lago Viedma in Los Glaciares. There is a campsite here for trekkers who are following the Huemul Circuit.

description.web: Lago Argentino is located in the Los Glaciares National Park, Patagonia, Argentina. It is the largest freshwater lake in Argentina, covering 1,415km². Its northwestern arm leads to Upsala Glacier, while the south-southwestern arm ends at Perito Moreno Glacier.

description.web: A stunning snow-capped volcano that lies on the southeastern shore of the huge Llanquihue Lake, one-two hours from the Chilean town of Puerto Varas, and near to the popular Petrohue waterfalls. This active volcano stands at 2,652 metres above sea level. There's a wonderful 4-7 hour hike around the volcano for those wanting a 360 perspective on the volcano and its surrounding lakes, and for the more adventurous you can hike up to the summit of the volcano. Be prepared for a very early start, dawn ascent and crampons and ice axe for the final push to the summit. Find out more about Technical Volcano Hikes >>

description.web: Karukinka Natural Park is a private natural park, established in 2004 and located on the Chilean part of the Isla Grande de Tierra del Fuego. The land for the park was donated to the Wildlife Conservation Society by Goldman Sachs.

description.web: Nestled slightly away from the crowds of trekkers heading to Laguna Torre, this basic yet protected camping area is reserved for authorised park outfitters only. Here you'll find simple base-camp tents for communal use at meal times, and smaller tents for trekkers to retire to for the night. Basic drop toilets are available.

description.web: Isla de los Estados is an island in Argentina, located 29 kilometres (18 miles) to the east of Tierra del Fuego, from which it is separated by the Le Maire Strait. The island is part of the Argentine province of Tierra del Fuego and has been awarded the status of an 'Ecological, Historic, and Tourist Provincial Reserve'.

description.web: Refugio Eduardo García Soto is a mountain hut located within Bernardo O'Higgins National Park in the Aysén region of Chile. It sits at an elevation of 1,600m and is a key point on several trekking routes in the area. The hut is a basic structure with no faciltiies. It will be visited on a trek to Cerro Gorra Blanca.
